884219_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Viad Corp (together with its subsidiaries, Viad or the Company ) derives its revenues from services provided primarily within the exhibition and events industry and travel and recreation industry.
884219_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	Viad occupies leading positions as a value added service provider in many of the markets in which it competes.
884219_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	Viad serves clients predominantly in North America, the United Kingdom, Germany and the United Arab Emirates.
884219_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	Viad organizes its businesses into two main operating groups:
884219_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The Marketing Events Group specializes in all aspects of the design, planning and production of face-to-face events, immersive environments and brand-based experiences for clients, including show organizers, corporate brand marketers and retail shopping centers.
884219_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	The mission of the Marketing Events Group is to create the world s most meaningful and memorable experiences for brand marketers, show organizers, event attendees and retail shopping centers.
884219_11_ITEM1_P2_S2	Show organizers include for-profit and not-for-profit show owners as well as show management companies.
884219_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Corporate brand marketers include exhibitors and domestic and international corporations which want to promote their brand, feature new products, services and innovations, and build business relationships.
884219_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	Retail shopping centers include major developers, owners and management companies of shopping malls and lifestyle centers.
884219_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Travel Recreation Group generates its revenues from tourism products and services including world-class attractions, hotel and concession operations, transportation services and package tour operations in and around Western Canada, Glacier National Park in Montana and Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, Canada.
884219_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	Viad s two business groups are supported by a centralized Corporate Services Group, which provides functional support in the areas of human resources, legal, finance and accounting, internal auditing, information technology, corporate development, real estate and tax.
884219_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	With the two business groups, Viad s organizational structure, operational decision-making authority, allocation of resources and internal reporting are aligned into the following reportable business segments:
884219_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	No reportable segment has a client comprising more than six percent of that segment s revenues, and no client comprises more than four percent of Viad s revenues.
884219_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	Viad s reportable business segments are described below.
884219_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	The Marketing Events U.S. segment includes the domestic operations of Global Experience Specialists, Inc. ( GES ) and affiliates, including those services formerly provided under the Exhibitgroup/Giltspur and Becker Group brands.
884219_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	This segment generates revenues from the following services:
884219_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	Under agreements with show organizers, the Marketing Events U.S. segment serves as the official services contractor of an exhibition, which is also referred to as a trade show, convention, or show.
884219_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	As the official services contractor, the U.S. segment provides the following services to the show organizer: general event management; planning and consultation; concept design; exhibition layout and design; graphics and design; show traffic analysis; carpeting and flooring; decorating products and accessories; custom graphics; overhead rigging; cleaning; and temporary electrical, lighting and plumbing.
884219_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	As the official services contractor, the U.S. segment is designated by the show organizer as the exclusive provider of certain services offered to exhibitors participating in the exhibition.
884219_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	This designation provides exhibitors with a single point of contact to facilitate a timely, safe and efficient move-in and move-out of the exhibition.
884219_11_ITEM1_P11_S2	The exclusive services offered by the U.S. segment to exhibitors include: material handling services; overhead rigging; temporary electrical and plumbing; and cleaning.
884219_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	construction; portable and modular exhibits and design; integrated marketing, including pre- and post-event communications and customer relationship management; multimedia services; event surveys; return on investment analysis; attendee and exhibit booth traffic analysis; staff training; online management tools; logistics and freight-forwarding, storage and refurbishment of exhibits; booth furnishings, carpeting and signage; in-house installation and dismantling; and various other show services.
884219_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	The U.S. segment aims to provide these services, combined with complete event program management and planning, to corporate brand marketers across all exhibitions and events in which they participate.
884219_11_ITEM1_P12_S2	The U.S. segment competes with other service providers to offer these discretionary services to exhibitors, regardless of whether or not the U.S. segment is the official services contractor of the exhibition.
884219_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	The U.S. segment also provides a variety of immersive, entertaining attractions and brand-based experiences, sponsored events, mobile marketing and other branded entertainment and face-to-face marketing solutions for clients and venues, including shopping malls, movie studios, museums, leading consumer brands and casinos.
884219_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	In addition, the U.S. segment offers retail clients complete turnkey services, including design, engineering, graphic production, fabrication, warehousing, shipping, and on-site installation of retail merchandising units, kiosks and holiday environments.
884219_11_ITEM1_P13_S2	The U.S. segment also provides construction and installation services for permanent installations, including museum exhibits, corporate lobbies, visitors centers, showrooms, and retail interiors.
884219_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	The U.S. segment generally competes in the exhibition and events industry on the basis of discernible differences, value, quality, price, convenience and service.
884219_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	Viad believes the primary competitor in the domestic official services contractor market is The Freeman Companies (a private company), however, the U.S. segment encounters substantial competition from a large number of providers of similar services.
884219_11_ITEM1_P14_S2	No competitor has significant market share in the other service categories.
884219_11_ITEM1_P14_S3	Most of the competitors are privately held companies with limited information available about them.
884219_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	During 2010, the U.S. segment provided services to over 1,350 exhibitions and events and more than 163,000 exhibitors.
884219_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	The U.S. segment has full-service operations in every major exhibition market in the U.S., including: Las Vegas, Nevada; Chicago, Illinois; Orlando, Florida; New York, New York and Los Angeles, California.
884219_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	In each of these locations, the U.S. segment is a leading service provider, servicing some of the most visible and influential events in its industry.
884219_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	The Marketing Events International segment includes all foreign operations of the Marketing Events Group and consists of two operating segments: Canada and EMEA (Europe, Middle East, Asia).
884219_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The International segment offers services that are similar to those provided by the U.S. segment.
884219_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	These services are delivered by Viad s wholly owned subsidiaries, including: GES Exposition Services (Canada) Limited, Melville Exhibition and Event Services Limited and affiliates (collectively Melville ), SDD Exhibitions Limited and GES GmbH Co. KG.
884219_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	During 2010, the International segment provided services to over 550 exhibitions and events and more than 48,000 exhibitors.
884219_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	The International segment has full-service operations in many of the most active and popular exhibition and event destinations, including 10 Canadian cities, six United Kingdom cities, one German city, and two cities in the United Arab Emirates.
884219_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	In each location, the International segment is a leading service provider, servicing some of the most visible and influential events in its industry.
884219_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	The International segment generally competes on the basis of discernible differences, value, quality, price, convenience and service.
884219_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	This segment is the largest exhibitions competitor in countries in which it competes.
884219_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	The International segment encounters competition from a large number of providers of similar services.
884219_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	Most of the competitors are privately held companies, with limited information available about them.
884219_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	Travel and recreation services are provided by Brewster Inc. ( Brewster ) and Glacier Park, Inc. ( Glacier Park ).
884219_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	Glacier Park is an 80 percent owned subsidiary of Viad.
884219_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	Brewster is a major tourism service operator in Western Canada, delivering tourism products that include world-class attractions, transportation services, inbound package tour operations, hotel operations and corporate and event management.
884219_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	Brewster s attractions include the Banff Gondola, tours of the Athabasca Glacier on the Columbia Icefield and the Banff Lake Cruise operations.
884219_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	of Banff and the Bow Valley.
884219_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	Tours of the Athabasca Glacier on the Columbia Icefield provide clients with an opportunity to experience one of the largest accumulations of ice and snow south of the Arctic Circle.
884219_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	Icefield customers ride in an Ice Explorer, a unique vehicle specially designed for glacier travel.
884219_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	Brewster also offers boat tours, small boat rentals and charter fishing on Lake Minnewanka, which is situated outside of the town of Banff in the heart of the Canadian Rockies.
884219_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	Brewster s transportation operations include charter motorcoach services, sightseeing and scheduled services and airport service.
884219_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Brewster operates a modern fleet of luxury motorcoaches, available for groups of any size, for travel throughout the Canadian provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.
884219_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	In addition, Brewster provides year-round half- and full-day sightseeing tours from Calgary, Banff, Lake Louise and Jasper, Canada.
884219_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	Package Tour Operations and Corporate and Event Management.
884219_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Brewster s inbound package tour operations feature year-round package tours throughout Canada.
884219_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	These packages include motorcoach, rail, self-drive automobile, ski and winter touring and consist of both group and individual tours which may be custom designed at the time of booking.
884219_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	Brewster also offers a full suite of corporate and event management services for meetings, conferences, incentive travel, sports and special events.
884219_11_ITEM1_P29_S3	Event-related service offerings include staffing, off-site events, tours/activities, team building, housing, event management, theme development, production and audio visual services.
884219_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Brewster operates two hotels in Alberta: the Mount Royal Hotel, which is located in the heart of Banff, and the Glacier View Inn (formerly, the Columbia Icefield Chalet), which is located on the Columbia Icefields between Lake Louise and Jasper.
884219_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	The hotels cater principally to leisure travelers.
884219_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	Brewster draws its customers from major markets including Canada, the U.S., the United Kingdom, Australia/New Zealand and Asia.
884219_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	Brewster markets directly to consumers, as well as through distribution channels that include tour operators, tour wholesalers, destination management companies and retail travel agencies/organizations.
884219_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	In October 2010, Brewster Travel Canada became the new brand identity of Brewster.
884219_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	Glacier Park is an independent hotel operator and concessionaire of Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park, which encompasses Glacier National Park in Montana and Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, Canada.
884219_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	Glacier Park is the largest concessionaire in Glacier National Park which is among the most visited National Parks in the U.S.
884219_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	Glacier Park provides lodging accommodations, food and beverage services, retail operations, transportation services and tours throughout Glacier and Waterton-Lakes National Parks.
884219_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	The operations of Glacier Park are seasonal, typically running from mid-May until the end of September.
884219_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	During those months, Glacier and Waterton Lakes National Parks typically host over two million visitors, the vast majority of whom purchase services from Glacier Park.
884219_11_ITEM1_P34_S2	During the peak months of July and August, the occupancy level at Glacier Park s lodges and motor inns typically exceeds 90 percent.
884219_11_ITEM1_P34_S3	During the shoulder months of June and September, occupancy typically exceeds 80 percent.
884219_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	Individual travelers account for over 80 percent of Glacier Park s customers, and the balance of its customers are tour groups.
884219_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	Demographically, Glacier Park draws over 90 percent of its customers from the U.S., with approximately 50 percent of them coming from the Northwest and Midwest regions.
884219_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	Glacier Park operates four historic lodges and three 1960s-era motor inns, with accommodation offerings varying from hikers cabins to suites.
884219_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	In January 2011, Glacier Park acquired a 145-room hotel in Whitefish, Montana, which is near Glacier National Park.
884219_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	Glacier Park has food and beverage operations providing services to lodging guests and park visitors.
884219_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	Glacier Park also has retail operations, including a camp store and gift shops catering to lodging guests and park visitors.
884219_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	Glacier Park utilizes a fleet of authentic 1930s red touring buses that have rollback canvas tops to conduct interpretive park tours throughout Glacier and Waterton Lakes National Parks, including tours of the scenic Going-to-the-Sun Road.
884219_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Glacier Park operates the concession portion of its business under a concession contract with the U.S. National Park Service (the Park Service ) for Glacier National Park.
884219_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	Glacier Park s original 25-year concession contract with the Park Service that was to expire on December 31, 2005, has been extended for six one-year periods and now expires on December 31, 2011.
884219_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	When this contract ultimately expires, Glacier Park will have the opportunity to bid on a new concession contract.
884219_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	If Glacier Park does secure a new contract, possible terms would be for 10, 15 or 20 years.
884219_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Glacier Park generated approximately 70 percent of its 2010 revenue through its concession contract for services provided within Glacier National Park.
884219_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	If a new concessionaire is selected by the Park Service, Glacier Park s remaining business would consist of its operations at Waterton Lakes National Park; East Glacier, Montana and Whitefish, Montana.
884219_11_ITEM1_P41_S2	In such a circumstance, Glacier Park would be entitled to an amount equal to its possessory interest, which generally means the value of the structures acquired or constructed, fixtures installed and improvements made to the concession property at Glacier National Park during the term of the concession contract.
884219_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Glacier Park owns its Glacier Park Lodge operations in East Glacier, Montana as well as the Grouse Mountain Lodge in Whitefish, Montana (acquired January 5, 2011).
884219_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	Glacier Park also owns the Prince of Wales Hotel in Waterton Lakes National Park, which is operated under a ground lease with the Canadian Government that was recently renewed for a 42-year term running through January 31, 2052.
884219_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Glacier Park generated approximately 25 percent of the Travel Recreation Group s full year 2010 segment operating income.
884219_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Viad s Travel Recreation Group segment generally competes on the basis of location, uniqueness of facilities, service, quality and price.
884219_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Competition exists both locally and regionally in the package-tour business, hotel and restaurant business and charter service business.
884219_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	Over the past two years, Viad reorganized its structure and rebranded its services.
884219_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	In July 2009, Viad announced a strategic reorganization to align operations into two groups: the Marketing Events Group and the Travel Recreation Group .
884219_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	The two groups are described above.
884219_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	On the close of business on December 31, 2009, the operations of the Marketing Events U.S. segment were combined into Global Experience Specialists, Inc. (such operations being formerly known as GES Expositions Services, Inc., Exhibitgroup/Giltspur and The Becker Group).
884219_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	On February 2, 2010, the Marketing Events Group introduced Global Experience Specialists as its new brand which is used in connection with all of the Marketing Events Group s services, replacing the GES Exposition Services, Exhibitgroup/Giltspur and Becker Group brands.
884219_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	Additionally, Viad has made acquisitions and strategic investments to grow its business.
884219_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	Viad expanded into the major exhibition venues of the United Kingdom with the acquisition of Melville in February 2007.
884219_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	Melville provided Viad with a platform to continue its international expansion.
884219_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	In late 2007, Viad expanded into Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, and is the exclusive provider of venue services for exhibitions and events at the Abu Dhabi National Exhibitions Centre (ADNEC).
884219_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	In January 2009, Viad extended its logistics and freight forwarding services business into continental Europe by launching a Melville operation in Germany.
884219_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	In late 2009, Viad further expanded into the United Arab Emirates by opening an operation in Dubai, which serviced its first exhibition as the official services contractor in February 2010.
884219_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	On January 4, 2008, Viad acquired The Becker Group.
884219_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	The Becker Group s lines of business specialized in creating immersive, entertaining attractions and brand-based experiences for year-round branded attractions, sponsored events, mobile marketing tours, retail marketing (including retail merchandising units, kiosks and holiday environments) and other place-based marketing solutions.
884219_11_ITEM1_P53_S1	These lines of business are now a part of GES within Viad s Marketing Events Group.
884219_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Most recently, on January 5, 2011, Viad acquired Grouse Mountain Lodge, a 145-room, four-season resort hotel located in Whitefish, Montana.
884219_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	The hotel will be operated by Glacier Park within Viad s Travel Recreation Group segment.

884219_11_ITEM1_P58_S1	These include patents relating to modular furniture used in exhibits and displays and a modular structure having a load-bearing surface.

884219_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Viad s operating results are subject to known and unknown risks.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	As a result, past financial performance and historical trends may not be reliable indicators of future performance.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Viad s businesses and operating results are adversely affected by deterioration in general economic conditions.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Viad s businesses are sensitive to fluctuations in general economic conditions and are impacted by increases and decreases in the cost of materials and operating supplies.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Operating results for the Marketing Events U.S. and International segments depend largely on the number of exhibitions held and on the size of exhibitors marketing expenditures, which in turn depend partly on the strength of particular industries in which exhibitors operate.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	The number and size of exhibitions generally decrease when the economy weakens.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Further, many exhibitors marketing budgets are partly discretionary, and are frequently among the first expenditures reduced by exhibitors when economic conditions deteriorate, resulting in reduced spending by exhibitors for the Company s services.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Marketing expenditures often are not increased until economic conditions improve.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	As a result, during periods of general economic weakness, the operating results for the Marketing Events Group are adversely affected.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Similarly, many of the retail shopping mall and lifestyle center clients of the Marketing Events Group may reduce marketing expenditures when economic conditions deteriorate.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Revenues from the Travel Recreation Group businesses depend largely on the amount of disposable income that consumers have available for travel and vacations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	This amount decreases during periods of weak general economic conditions.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Viad s results of operations are impacted by changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Viad conducts foreign operations primarily in Canada, the United Kingdom and, to a lesser extent, in certain other countries.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P7_S1	The functional currency of Viad s foreign subsidiaries is their local currency.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	translates the assets and liabilities of its foreign subsidiaries into U.S. dollars at the foreign exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	The unrealized gains or losses resulting from the translation of these foreign denominated assets and liabilities are included as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income in Viad s consolidated balance sheets.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Significant fluctuations in foreign exchange rates relative to the U.S. dollar may result in material changes to Viad s net equity position reported in its consolidated balance sheets.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Viad has not hedged its equity risk arising from the translation of foreign denominated assets and liabilities.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	In addition, for purposes of consolidation, the revenues, expenses and gains and losses related to Viad s foreign operations are translated into U.S. dollars at the average foreign exchange rates for the period.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	As a result, Viad s consolidated results of operations are exposed to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, even when the functional currency amounts have not changed.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Accordingly, fluctuations in the exchange rates affect overall profitability and historical period to period comparisons.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Viad has not hedged its net earnings exposure arising from the translation of its foreign operating results.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	During 2010, $165.0 million of revenue and $9.5 million of operating income was derived through Canadian and United Kingdom operations of Viad s Marketing Events International segment.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In addition, $64.2 million of 2010 revenue and $15.8 million of 2010 operating income generated in the Travel Recreation Group segment was derived through its Canadian operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	For this segment, Canadian operations are largely dependent on foreign customer visitation, and accordingly, increases in the value of the Canadian dollar compared to other currencies could adversely affect customer volumes, and therefore, revenue and operating income in the Travel Recreation Group segment.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Exhibition rotation impacts overall profitability and makes comparisons between periods difficult.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The business activities of the Marketing Events Group are largely dependent upon the frequency, timing and location of exhibitions and events.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Some large exhibitions are not held annually (they may be held once every two or three years or longer).
884219_11_ITEM1A_P14_S2	Some large exhibitions may be held at a different time of year than when they have historically been held.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P14_S3	In addition, the same exhibition may be held in different locations in different years, and may result in Viad generating lower margins in a given period if the exhibition shifts to a higher-cost city.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	As a consequence of these factors, the operating results for these businesses may fluctuate significantly from quarter to quarter or from year to year, making periodic comparisons difficult.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Viad s businesses are adversely affected by disruptions in the travel industry, particularly those adversely affecting the hotel and airline industries.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The success of Viad s businesses depends largely on the ability and willingness of people, whether exhibitors, exhibition attendees or others, to travel.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Factors adversely affecting the travel industry as a whole, and particularly the airline and hotel industries, generally also adversely affect Viad s businesses and results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Factors that could adversely affect the travel industry as a whole include high or rising fuel prices, increased security and passport requirements, weather conditions, airline accidents and international political instability and hostilities.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Unexpected events of this nature, or other events that may have an impact on the availability and pricing of air travel and accommodations, could adversely affect Viad s businesses and results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The failure of a large client to renew its services contract or the loss of business from convention facilities could adversely impact revenues.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Although no single client accounts for more than five percent of the revenue of any of Viad s reporting segments, the Marketing Events U.S. and International segments have a relatively small number of large exhibition show organizers and large customer accounts.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	The loss of any of these large clients would adversely affect results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	In addition, revenues of the Marketing Events Group may be significantly impacted if certain exhibition facilities choose to in-source electrical, plumbing and other services.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P20_S1	When the Marketing Events Group is hired as the official services contractor for an exhibition, the show organizer contractually grants an exclusive right to perform these electrical and plumbing services, subject in each case to the exhibition facility s option to in-source the services (either by performing the services themselves or by hiring a separate service provider).
884219_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Many exhibition facilities are under financial pressure as a result of conditions generally affecting their industry, including an increased supply of exhibitions space.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	As a result, some of these facilities have sought to in-source all or a large portion of these services.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	If a large number of facilities with which the Marketing Events Group has these relationships seek to move these services in-house, Viad s revenues and operating results could be adversely affected.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Viad s key businesses are relationship driven.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	The business activities of the Marketing Events U.S. and International segments are heavily focused on client relationships, and, specifically, on the close collaboration and interaction with the client.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	These relationships require the account team to become attuned to the client s desires and expectations in order to provide top-quality service.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Viad has in the past lost, and may in the future lose, important clients (and corresponding revenues) if a key member of the account team were to cease employment with the Company and take that customer to a competitor.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Completed acquisitions may not perform as anticipated or be integrated as planned.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Viad has acquired businesses and intends to continue to pursue opportunities to acquire businesses that could complement, enhance or expand Viad s current businesses or offer growth opportunities to Viad.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Any acquisition can involve a number of risks, including: the failure to achieve the financial and strategic goals and other benefits from the acquisition; the inability to successfully integrate the acquired business into Viad s ongoing businesses; the inability to retain key personnel or customers of the acquired business; the inability to successfully integrate financial reporting and internal control systems; the disruption of Viad s ongoing businesses and distraction of senior management and employees of Viad from other opportunities and challenges due to the integration of the acquired business; and the potential existence of liabilities or contingencies not disclosed to or known by Viad prior to closing the acquisition or not otherwise provided for through the purchase agreement.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Viad s businesses are seasonal, which causes results of operations to fluctuate and makes results of operations particularly sensitive to adverse events during peak periods.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	The Marketing Events U.S. segment generally reports its highest revenues during the first quarter of each year, while the Marketing Events International segment generally reports its highest revenues during the second quarter of each year.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	The Travel Recreation Group businesses are also seasonal, experiencing peak activity during the second and third quarters; these quarters accounted for 84 percent of the segment s 2010 revenues.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Because of the seasonal nature of Viad s businesses, adverse events or conditions occurring during peak periods could reduce the operating results of Viad s businesses.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Transportation disruptions and increases in transportation costs could adversely affect Viad s businesses and operating results.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	The Marketing Events U.S. and International segments rely on independent transportation carriers to send materials and exhibits to and from exhibitions, warehouse facilities and customer facilities.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	If they were unable to secure the services of these independent transportation carriers at favorable rates, it could have a material adverse effect on these businesses and their results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P30_S2	In addition, disruption of transportation services because of weather-related problems, strikes, lockouts or other events could adversely affect their ability to supply services to customers and could cause the cancellation of exhibitions, which may have a material adverse effect on these businesses and operating results.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P30_S3	Similarly, disruption of transportation services could adversely affect the ability of the Marketing Events Group to supply time-sensitive holiday-themed exhibits and experiences to retail shopping mall and lifestyle center customers and could cause the cancellation of the exhibits and experiences.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Union-represented labor creates an increased risk of work stoppages and higher labor costs.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	A significant portion of Viad s employees are unionized and Viad s businesses are party to approximately 100 collective-bargaining agreements, with approximately one-fourth requiring renegotiation each year.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P32_S1	If the results of labor negotiations caused the Company to increase wages or benefits, which increases total labor costs, the increased costs could either be absorbed (which would adversely affect operating margins) or passed on to the customers, which may lead customers to turn to other vendors in response to higher prices.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P32_S2	In either event, Viad s businesses and results of operations could be adversely affected.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Moreover, if the Company were unable to reach an agreement with a union during the collective bargaining process, the union may strike or carry-out other types of work stoppages.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P33_S1	In such a circumstance, Viad might be unable to find substitute workers with the necessary skills to perform many of the services, or may incur additional costs to do so, which could adversely affect the Company s businesses and results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Obligations to fund multi-employer pension plans to which Viad contributes may have an adverse impact on operating results.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	Viad s businesses contribute to various multi-employer pension plans based on obligations arising under collective bargaining agreements covering its union-represented employees.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P35_S1	Viad s contributions to these multi-employer plans in 2010 and 2009 totaled $15.3 million and $15.7 million, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Based upon the information available to Viad from plan administrators, management believes that several of these multi-employer plans are underfunded.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	The Pension Protection Act of 2006 requires pension plans underfunded at certain levels to reduce, over defined time periods, the underfunded status.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P37_S1	In addition, under current laws, the termination of a plan, or a voluntary withdrawal from a plan by Viad, or a shrinking contribution base to a plan as a result of the insolvency or withdrawal of other contributing employers to such plan would require Viad to make payments to such plan for its proportionate share of the plan s unfunded vested liabilities.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P37_S2	Viad cannot determine at this time the amount of additional funding, if any, it may be required to make to these plans.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P37_S3	However, plan contribution increases, if any, could have an adverse impact on Viad s consolidated financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Viad competes in competitive industries and increased competition could negatively impact operating results.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Viad is engaged in a number of highly competitive industries.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P39_S1	Competition in the exhibition and events industry and the exhibits and experiential environments industries is driven by price and service quality, among other factors.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P39_S2	To the extent competitors seek to gain or retain their market presence through aggressive underpricing strategies, Viad may be required to lower its prices and rates to avoid loss of related business, thereby adversely affecting operating results.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P39_S3	In addition, if Viad is unable to anticipate and respond as effectively as competitors to changing business conditions, including new technologies and business models, Viad could lose market share to its competitors.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	If Viad were unable to meet the challenges presented by the competitive environment, results of operations could be adversely affected.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Liabilities relating to prior and discontinued operations may adversely affect results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Viad and its predecessors have a corporate history spanning over seven decades and involving approximately 2,400 previous subsidiaries in diverse businesses, such as the manufacturing of locomotives, buses, industrial chemicals, fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, leather, textiles, food and fresh meats.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P42_S1	Some of these businesses used raw materials that have been, and may continue to be, the subject of litigation.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P42_S2	Moreover, some of the raw materials used and the waste produced by these businesses have been and are the subject of U.S. federal and state environmental regulations, including laws enacted under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act, or its state law counterparts.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P42_S3	In addition, Viad may incur other liabilities, resulting from indemnification claims involving sold subsidiaries, as well as from past operations of those of predecessors or their subsidiaries.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P42_S4	Although the Company believes it has adequate reserves and sufficient insurance coverage to cover these future liabilities, results of operations could be materially affected if future events or proceedings contradict current assumptions, and reserves or insurance become inadequate.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Terrorist attacks, natural disasters or other catastrophic events may have a negative effect on Viad s business.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P44_S0	The occurrence of catastrophic events ranging from natural disasters (such as hurricanes), health epidemics or pandemics, acts of war or terrorism, or the prospect of these events could disrupt Viad s businesses.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Such catastrophic events could impact our production facilities preventing us from timely completing exhibit fabrication and other projects for customers, and also could cause a disruption in the services we provide to our customers at convention centers, exhibition halls, hotels and other public venues.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P44_S2	Such catastrophic events also could cause a cancellation of exhibitions and other events held in public venues.
884219_11_ITEM1A_P44_S3	If the conditions arising from such events persist or worsen, Viad could experience continuing or increased adverse effects on its results of operations and financial condition.
884219_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	Viad s businesses operate service or production facilities and maintain sales and service offices in the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany and the United Arab Emirates.
884219_11_ITEM2_P0_S1	The principal properties of Viad s businesses as of December 31, 2010, were:
884219_11_ITEM2_P1_S0	Viad s headquarters are located at 1850 North Central Avenue, Suite 800 in Phoenix, Arizona 85004-4545.
884219_11_ITEM2_P1_S1	Excluding space which is subleased to third parties, Viad leases approximately 59,400 square feet.
884219_11_ITEM2_P2_S0	The Marketing Events U.S. segment operates 20 offices and 28 multi-use facilities (manufacturing, sales and design, office and/or warehouse and truck marshaling yards).
884219_11_ITEM2_P2_S1	The multi-use facilities vary in size up to approximately 590,900 square feet.
884219_11_ITEM2_P2_S2	Three of the multi-use facilities are owned; all other properties are leased.

884219_11_ITEM2_P3_S1	The multi-use facilities vary in size up to approximately 134,000 square feet.
884219_11_ITEM2_P3_S2	One of the multi-use facilities is owned; all other properties are leased.
884219_11_ITEM2_P4_S0	The Travel Recreation Group segment operates two offices, nine retail stores, one bus terminal, three garages, an icefield tour facility, a gondola lift operation, a boat tour facility and nine hotels/lodges (with approximately 900 rooms and ancillary foodservice and recreational facilities).
884219_11_ITEM2_P4_S1	All of the facilities are in the United States or Canada.

884219_11_ITEM2_P4_S4	The icefield tour facility and gondola lift operation are operated through lease agreements with Parks Canada and all other properties are leased.

884219_11_ITEM2_P5_S0	Management believes that the Company s facilities in the aggregate are adequate and suitable for their purposes and that capacity is sufficient for current needs.
884219_11_ITEM3_P0_S0	Viad and certain subsidiaries are plaintiffs or defendants to various actions, proceedings and pending claims, some of which involve, or may involve, compensatory, punitive or other damages.
884219_11_ITEM3_P0_S1	Litigation is subject to many uncertainties and it is possible that some of the legal actions, proceedings or claims could be decided against Viad.
884219_11_ITEM3_P0_S2	Although the amount of liability as of December 31, 2010 with respect to certain of these matters is not ascertainable, Viad believes that any resulting liability, after taking into consideration amounts already provided for, including insurance coverage, will not have a material effect on Viad s business, financial condition or results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM3_P1_S0	Viad is subject to various U.S. federal, state and foreign laws and regulations governing the prevention of pollution and the protection of the environment in the jurisdictions in which Viad has or had operations.
884219_11_ITEM3_P1_S1	If the Company has failed to comply with these environmental laws and regulations, civil and criminal penalties could be imposed and Viad could become subject to regulatory enforcement actions in the form of injunctions and cease and desist orders.
884219_11_ITEM3_P1_S2	As is the case with many companies, Viad also faces exposure for actual or potential claims and lawsuits involving environmental matters relating to its past operations.
884219_11_ITEM3_P1_S3	Although it is a party to certain environmental disputes, Viad believes that any resulting liabilities, after taking into consideration amounts already provided for, including insurance coverage, will not have a material effect on the Company s financial condition or results of operations.

884219_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with Viad Corp s consolidated financial statements and related notes.
884219_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	This discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
884219_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	Viad Corp s actual results could differ materially from those anticipated due to various factors discussed under Risk Factors, Forward-Looking Statements and elsewhere in this Annual Report.
884219_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Viad s reportable segments consist of Marketing Events U.S., Marketing Events International and Travel Recreation Group.
884219_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	In July 2009, Viad announced a strategic reorganization to align its brands and operations into two operating groups: the Marketing Events Group and the Travel Recreation Group.
884219_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	The operating groups are supported by a Corporate Services Group that centralizes responsibility for various corporate functions.
884219_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	On the close of business on December 31, 2009, substantially all of the domestic operations of the Marketing Events Group were combined into one legal entity by transferring all of the assets and third party liabilities of Exhibitgroup/Giltspur, a division of Viad Corp, The Becker Group, Ltd. ( Becker Group ) and other related entities into GES Exposition Services, Inc.
884219_11_ITEM7_P4_S3	Furthermore, on February 2, 2010, GES Exposition Services, Inc. changed its name to Global Experience Specialists, Inc. ( GES ).
884219_11_ITEM7_P4_S4	The services that were previously provided under the Company s brands of Exhibitgroup/Giltspur and Becker Group are now provided under the Global Experience Specialists brand.
884219_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	Beginning in 2010, the Company changed its reportable segments as a result of the reorganization and consolidation of business units within the Marketing Events Group.
884219_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	The reportable segments are based on geographical lines of responsibility and reflect the management structure and internal organization of the business.
884219_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	Accordingly, the presentation of segment information for the Marketing Events Group is based on the redefined segments, and comparable information for earlier periods has been restated to reflect the revised segment structure.
884219_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Marketing Events Group specializes in all aspects of the design, planning and production of face-to-face events, immersive environments and brand-based experiences for clients, including show organizers, corporate brand marketers and retail shopping centers.
884219_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	In addition, the Marketing Events Group provides a variety of immersive, entertaining attractions and brand-based experiences, sponsored events, mobile marketing and other branded entertainment and face-to-face marketing solutions for clients and venues, including shopping malls, movie studios, museums, leading consumer brands and casinos.
884219_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	The composition of the Marketing Events Group s reportable segments reflects geographical lines of responsibility.
884219_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	segment includes all domestic GES and affiliated operations, including those services formerly provided under the Exhibitgroup/Giltspur and Becker Group brands.
884219_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The consolidation of the domestic Marketing Events Group operations is intended to provide a fully integrated service delivery network through a realigned sales organization, shared infrastructure and facilities, and a common operational platform.
884219_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	International segment includes all foreign operations of the Marketing Events Group and consists of two operating segments: Canada and EMEA (Europe, Middle East, Asia).

884219_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	The following 2010 financial highlights are presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( GAAP ):
884219_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	The following discussion includes a presentation of Adjusted EBITDA and Income before impairment losses, which are utilized by management to measure the profit and performance of Viad s operations and to facilitate period to period comparisons.
884219_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Adjusted EBITDA is defined by Viad as net income attributable to Viad before interest expense, income taxes, depreciation and amortization, impairment losses and recoveries, changes in accounting principles and the effects of discontinued operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	Income before impairment losses is defined by Viad as income from continuing operations before the after-tax effect of impairment losses related to goodwill, other intangible assets and other long-lived assets.
884219_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	The presentation of Adjusted EBITDA and Income before impairment losses is supplemental to results presented under GAAP and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
884219_11_ITEM7_P15_S3	Adjusted EBITDA is considered a useful operating metric as potential variations arising from taxes, depreciation, debt service costs, impairment losses and recoveries, changes in accounting principles and the effects of discontinued operations are eliminated, thus resulting in an additional measure considered to be indicative of Viad s ongoing operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P15_S4	Income before impairment losses is utilized by management to review operating results of the business without the effects of non-cash impairment losses.
884219_11_ITEM7_P15_S5	These non-GAAP measures should be considered in addition to, but not as a substitute for, other measures of financial performance reported in accordance with GAAP.
884219_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Management believes that the presentation of Adjusted EBITDA and Income before impairment losses provides useful information to investors regarding Viad s results of operations for trending, analyzing and benchmarking the performance and value of Viad s business.
884219_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	Management uses Adjusted EBITDA and Income before impairment losses primarily as performance measures and believes that the GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to these non-GAAP measures are net income attributable to Viad and income from continuing operations attributable to Viad, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	Although Adjusted EBITDA is used as a financial measure to assess the performance of the business, the use of Adjusted EBITDA is limited because it does not consider material costs, expenses and other items necessary to operate the business.
884219_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	non-cash depreciation and amortization expense associated with long-lived assets, expenses related to U.S. federal, state, local and foreign income taxes, impairment losses or recoveries, and the effects of accounting changes and discontinued operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	Similarly, although Income before impairment losses is used as a financial measure to assess the performance of the business, its use is limited because it does not consider non-cash goodwill, other intangible asset and other long-lived asset impairment losses.
884219_11_ITEM7_P18_S2	Because Adjusted EBITDA and Income before impairment losses do not consider the above items, a user of Viad s financial information should consider net income attributable to Viad and income from continuing operations attributable to Viad as important measures of financial performance because they provide more complete measures of the Company s performance.

884219_11_ITEM7_P39_S4	If Glacier Park does secure a new contract, possible terms would be for 10, 15 or 20 years.

884219_11_ITEM7_P40_S2	In such a circumstance, Glacier Park would be entitled to an amount equal to its possessory interest, which generally means the value of the structures acquired or constructed, fixtures installed and improvements made to the concession property at Glacier National Park during the term of the concession contract.

884219_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	Effective November 20, 2009, Viad amended its secured revolving credit agreement (the Credit Facility ) to ensure that the Company continued to meet its obligations under the Credit Facility given the current economic environment.
884219_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	The amended Credit Facility provides for a $75 million revolving line of credit, which was lowered from $150 million, and may be increased up to an additional $50 million under certain circumstances.
884219_11_ITEM7_P69_S2	The Credit Facility borrowings are to be used for general corporate purposes (including permitted acquisitions) and to support up to $25 million of letters of credit.
884219_11_ITEM7_P69_S3	The lenders have a first perfected security interest in all of the personal property of Viad and GES, including 65 percent of the capital stock of top-tier foreign subsidiaries.
884219_11_ITEM7_P69_S4	Viad is in discussions with its agent bank on the renewal of the Credit Facility, and expects to have a Credit Facility in place before its June 15, 2011 expiration.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	Borrowings under the Credit Facility (of which GES is a guarantor) are indexed to the prime rate or the London Interbank Offered Rate ( LIBOR ), plus appropriate spreads tied to Viad s leverage ratio.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	Commitment fees and letters of credit fees are also tied to Viad s leverage ratio.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	The fees on the unused portion of the Credit Facility are currently 0.375 percent annually.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S3	As of December 31, 2010, Viad had $65.9 million of capacity remaining under its Credit Facility reflecting an outstanding borrowing of $4.5 million (indexed to LIBOR) and issued letters of credit of $4.6 million.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S4	As part of the amendment, Viad s financial covenants were revised to include a fixed-charge coverage ratio of not less than 1.00 to 1 and a leverage ratio (defined as total debt to Adjusted EBITDA) of not greater than 2.50 to 1.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S5	Additionally, Viad must maintain a consolidated minimum cash balance of $50 million.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S6	As of December 31, 2010, the fixed-charge coverage and leverage ratios were 1.29 to 1 and 0.71 to 1, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S7	Significant other covenants include limitations on: investments, common stock dividends, stock repurchases, additional indebtedness, sales/leases of assets, acquisitions, consolidations or mergers and liens on property.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S8	The terms of the Credit Facility restrict Viad from paying more than $5 million in dividends in the aggregate in any calendar year and also restrict the Company from repurchasing more than $10 million in the aggregate of the Company s common stock during the remainder of the Credit Facility term.
884219_11_ITEM7_P70_S9	As of December 31, 2010, Viad was in compliance with all covenants.

884219_11_ITEM7_P88_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities in the consolidated financial statements.
884219_11_ITEM7_P88_S1	The SEC has defined a company s most critical accounting policies as those that are most important to the portrayal of a company s financial position and results of operations, and that require a company to make its most difficult and subjective judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates of matters that are inherently uncertain.
884219_11_ITEM7_P88_S2	Based on these criteria, Viad has identified and discussed with its audit committee the following critical accounting policies and estimates pertaining to Viad, and the methodology and disclosures related to those estimates:
884219_11_ITEM7_P89_S0	Goodwill Goodwill is not amortized, but tested for impairment at the reporting unit level on an annual basis on October 31 of each year.
884219_11_ITEM7_P89_S1	Goodwill is also tested for impairment between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more-likely-than-not reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying amount.
884219_11_ITEM7_P89_S2	Viad s reporting units are defined, and goodwill is tested, at either an operating segment level or at the component level of an operating segment, depending on various factors including: the internal reporting structure of the operating segment, the level of integration among components, the sharing of assets among components and the benefits and likely recoverability of goodwill by the component s operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	As of December 31, 2010, Viad had total goodwill of $127.4 million consisting of $85.1 million related to the Marketing Events Group and $42.3 million related to the Travel Recreation Group.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S1	Within the Marketing Events Group, goodwill of $62.7 million relates to the Marketing Events U.S. segment and $22.4 million to the Marketing Events International segment.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S2	For impairment testing purposes, the goodwill related to the Marketing Events U.S. segment is assigned to and tested at the operating segment level, which represents all domestic operations of GES.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S3	Furthermore, the goodwill related to the Marketing Events International segment is assigned to and tested at the component level within the segment s geographical operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S4	As of December 31, 2010, the amount of goodwill assigned to the reporting units in the United Kingdom (Melville) and Canada was $13.3 million and $9.1 million, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S5	Also, as of December 31, 2010, the Brewster operating segment (within the Travel Recreation Group) had goodwill of $42.3 million.
884219_11_ITEM7_P90_S6	Brewster is considered a reporting unit for goodwill impairment testing purposes.
884219_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	Viad uses a discounted expected future cash flow methodology (income approach) in order to estimate the fair value of its reporting units for purposes of goodwill impairment testing.
884219_11_ITEM7_P91_S1	The estimates and assumptions regarding expected future cash flows, discount rates and terminal values require considerable judgment and are based on market conditions, financial forecasts, industry trends and historical experience.
884219_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	The most critical assumptions and estimates in determining the estimated fair value of its reporting units relate to the amounts and timing of expected future cash flows for each reporting unit and the reporting unit cost of capital (discount rate) applied to those cash flows.
884219_11_ITEM7_P92_S1	Furthermore, the assumed reporting unit cost of capital rates (discount rates) are estimated using a build-up method based on the perceived risk associated with the cash flows pertaining to the specific reporting unit.
884219_11_ITEM7_P92_S2	In order to assess the reasonableness of its fair value estimates, the Company performs a reconciliation of the aggregate fair values of its reporting units to Viad s market capitalization.
884219_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	As noted above, the estimates and assumptions regarding expected future cash flows, discount rates and terminal values require considerable judgment and are based on market conditions, financial forecasts, industry trends and historical experience.
884219_11_ITEM7_P93_S1	These estimates, however, have inherent uncertainties and different assumptions could lead to materially different results.
884219_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	As of December 31, 2010, Viad had aggregate goodwill of $127.4 million recorded in the consolidated balance sheets.
884219_11_ITEM7_P94_S1	Furthermore, as a result of the Company s most recent impairment analysis performed in the fourth quarter of 2010, the excess of the estimated fair values over the carrying values (expressed as a percentage of the carrying amounts) under step one of the impairment test were 80 percent, 69 percent and 69 percent, respectively, for each of the Marketing Events Group reporting units in the United States, the United Kingdom (Melville) and Canada.
884219_11_ITEM7_P94_S2	For the Brewster reporting unit, the excess of the estimated fair value over the carrying value was 50 percent as of the most recent impairment test.
884219_11_ITEM7_P94_S3	Due to continued uncertainties in the current economic environment, reductions in the Company s expected future revenue, operating income or cash flow forecasts and projections, or an increase in reporting unit cost of capital, could trigger additional goodwill impairment testing, which may result in impairment losses.
884219_11_ITEM7_P94_S4	Furthermore, management continues to monitor the market capitalization of the Company as ongoing declines in market capitalization could be indicative of possible goodwill impairment.
884219_11_ITEM7_P94_S5	See Results of Operations above and Note 3 of notes to consolidated financial statements for a discussion of goodwill impairment losses recorded during 2009 and 2008.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	Income taxes Viad is required to estimate and record provisions for income taxes in each of the jurisdictions in which the Company operates.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S1	Accordingly, the Company must estimate its actual current income tax liability, and assess temporary differences arising from the treatment of items for tax purposes as compared to the treatment for accounting purposes.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S2	These differences result in deferred tax assets and liabilities which are included in Viad s consolidated balance sheets.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S3	The Company must assess the likelihood that deferred tax assets will be recovered from future taxable income and to the extent that recovery is not likely, a valuation allowance must be established.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S4	The Company uses significant judgment in forming a conclusion regarding the recoverability of its deferred tax assets and evaluates the available positive and negative evidence to determine whether it is more-likely-than-not that its deferred tax assets will be realized in the future.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S5	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, Viad had gross deferred tax assets of $67.1 million and $61.2 million, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7_P95_S6	These deferred tax assets reflect the expected future tax benefits to be realized upon reversal of deductible temporary differences, and the utilization of net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
884219_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	During 2010 and 2009, Viad recorded pre-tax losses from its operations in the United States.
884219_11_ITEM7_P96_S1	The Company considered the negative evidence of these domestic pre-tax operating losses on the future recoverability of its deferred tax assets.
884219_11_ITEM7_P96_S2	Viad also considered positive evidence regarding the realization of deferred tax assets including the Company s historical and forecasted taxable income, taxpaying history and future reversals of deferred tax liabilities.
884219_11_ITEM7_P96_S3	Furthermore, Viad also considered the fact that goodwill impairment losses are not tax deductible and thus did not contribute to tax losses in 2009.
884219_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, Viad had a valuation allowance of $411,000 and $162,000, respectively, related to certain state deferred tax assets.
884219_11_ITEM7_P97_S1	With respect to all other deferred tax assets, management believes that recovery from future taxable income is more-likely-than-not.
884219_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	As noted above, Viad uses considerable judgment in forming a conclusion regarding the recoverability of its deferred tax assets.
884219_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	As a result, there are inherent uncertainties regarding the ultimate realization of these assets, which is primarily dependent on Viad s ability to generate sufficient taxable income in future periods.
884219_11_ITEM7_P98_S2	In light of the Company s recent domestic operating losses, and the continued uncertainties in the current economic environment, it is possible that the relative weight of positive and negative evidence regarding the recoverability of Viad s deferred tax assets may change, which could result in a material increase in the Company s valuation allowance.
884219_11_ITEM7_P98_S3	If such an increase in the valuation allowance were to occur, it would result in increased income tax expense in the period the assessment was made.
884219_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	Viad exercises judgment in determining its income tax provision due to transactions, credits and calculations where the ultimate tax determination is uncertain.
884219_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, Viad did not have any accrued gross liabilities associated with uncertain tax positions for continuing operations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P99_S2	However, as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, Viad had accrued interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions for continuing operations of $146,000 and $407,000, respectively.

884219_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	These tax resolutions primarily represent the reversal of amounts accrued for tax and related interest and penalties in connection with uncertain tax positions which were effectively settled or for which there was a lapse of the applicable statute of limitations.

884219_11_ITEM7_P101_S2	Future tax resolutions or settlements that may occur related to these uncertain tax positions would be recorded through discontinued operations (net of federal tax effects, if applicable).
884219_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	Insurance liabilities Viad is self-insured up to certain limits for workers compensation, automobile, product and general liability and property loss claims.
884219_11_ITEM7_P102_S1	The aggregate amount of insurance liabilities related to Viad s continuing operations was $22.6 million as of December 31, 2010.
884219_11_ITEM7_P102_S2	Of this total, $16.2 million related to workers compensation liabilities and the remaining $6.4 million related to general/auto liability claims.
884219_11_ITEM7_P102_S3	Viad has also retained and provided for certain insurance liabilities in conjunction with previously sold businesses totaling $7.5 million as of December 31, 2010, primarily related to workers compensation liabilities.
884219_11_ITEM7_P102_S4	Provisions for losses for claims incurred, including estimated claims incurred but not yet reported, are made based on Viad s historical experience, claims frequency and other factors.
884219_11_ITEM7_P102_S5	A change in the assumptions used could result in an adjustment to recorded liabilities.
884219_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	Viad has purchased insurance for amounts in excess of the self-insured levels, which generally range from $200,000 to $500,000 on a per claim basis.
884219_11_ITEM7_P103_S1	Viad does not maintain a self-insured retention pool fund as claims are paid from current cash resources at the time of settlement.

884219_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	Pension and postretirement benefits Viad s pension plans use traditional defined benefit formulas based on years of service and final average compensation.
884219_11_ITEM7_P104_S1	Funding policies provide that payments to defined benefit pension trusts shall be at least equal to the minimum funding required by applicable regulations.
884219_11_ITEM7_P104_S2	The Company presently anticipates contributing $1.6 million to its funded pension plans and $943,000 to its unfunded pension plans in 2011.
884219_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	Viad and certain of its subsidiaries have defined benefit postretirement plans that provide medical and life insurance for certain eligible employees, retirees and dependents.
884219_11_ITEM7_P105_S1	The related postretirement benefit liabilities are recognized over the period that services are provided by employees.
884219_11_ITEM7_P105_S2	In addition, Viad retained the obligations for these benefits for retirees of certain sold businesses.
884219_11_ITEM7_P105_S3	While the plans have no funding requirements, Viad expects to contribute $500,000 to the plans in 2011.
884219_11_ITEM7_P106_S0	The assumed health care cost trend rate used in measuring the December 31, 2010 accumulated postretirement benefit obligation was nine and one-half percent, declining one-half percent each year to the ultimate rate of five percent by the year 2019 and remaining at that level thereafter.
884219_11_ITEM7_P106_S1	The assumed health care cost trend rate used in measuring the December 31, 2009 accumulated postretirement benefit obligation was ten percent, declining one-half percent each year to the ultimate rate of five percent by the year 2019 and remaining at that level thereafter.
884219_11_ITEM7_P107_S0	A one-percentage-point increase in the assumed health care cost trend rate for each year would increase the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation as of December 31, 2010 by approximately $1.6 million and the total of service and interest cost components by approximately $124,000.
884219_11_ITEM7_P107_S1	A one-percentage-point decrease in the assumed health care cost trend rate for each year would decrease the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation as of December 31, 2010 by approximately $1.4 million and the total of service and interest cost components by approximately $104,000.

884219_11_ITEM7_P110_S0	The discount rates used in determining future pension and postretirement benefit obligations are based on rates determined by actuarial analysis and management review, and reflect the estimated rates of return on a high-quality, hypothetical bond portfolio whose cash flows match the timing and amounts of expected benefit payments.

884219_11_ITEM7_P111_S0	Share-based compensation Viad grants share-based compensation awards to officers, directors and certain key employees pursuant to the 2007 Viad Corp Omnibus Incentive Plan (the 2007 Plan ).
884219_11_ITEM7_P111_S1	The 2007 Plan has a ten-year life and provides for the following types of awards: (a) incentive and non-qualified stock options; (b) restricted stock and restricted stock units; (c) performance units or performance shares; (d) stock appreciation rights; (e) cash-based awards and (f) certain other stock-based awards.

884219_11_ITEM7_P112_S1	Furthermore, the total tax benefits related to such costs were $1.2 million, $1.1 million and $2.3 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7_P112_S2	No share-based compensation costs were capitalized during 2010, 2009 or 2008.
884219_11_ITEM7_P113_S0	The fair value of restricted stock and performance-based restricted stock awards are based on Viad s stock price on the date of grant.
884219_11_ITEM7_P113_S1	Liability-based awards are recorded at estimated fair value, based on the number of units expected to vest and the level of achievement of predefined performance goals (where applicable) and are remeasured on each balance sheet date based on Viad s stock price until the time of settlement.
884219_11_ITEM7_P114_S0	Viad uses the Black-Scholes option pricing model for purposes of determining the fair value of each stock option grant for which key assumptions are necessary.
884219_11_ITEM7_P114_S1	These assumptions include Viad s expected stock price volatility; the expected period of time the stock option will remain outstanding; the expected dividend yield on Viad common stock, and the risk-free interest rate.
884219_11_ITEM7_P114_S2	Changes in the assumptions could result in different estimates of the fair value of stock option grants, and consequently impact Viad s results of operations.

884219_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Viad s market risk exposures relate to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, interest rates and certain commodity prices.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Foreign exchange risk is the risk that fluctuating exchange rates will adversely affect financial condition or results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Interest rate risk is the risk that changing interest rates will adversely affect the earnings of Viad.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P2_S2	Commodity risk is the risk that changing prices will adversely affect results of operations.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Viad conducts its foreign operations primarily in Canada and the United Kingdom and to a lesser extent in certain other countries.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The functional currency of Viad s foreign subsidiaries is their local currency.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P3_S2	Accordingly, for purposes of consolidation, Viad translates the assets and liabilities of its foreign subsidiaries into U.S. dollars at the foreign exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P3_S3	The unrealized gains or losses resulting from the translation of these foreign denominated assets and liabilities are included as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income in Viad s consolidated balance sheets.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P3_S4	As a result, significant fluctuations in foreign exchange rates relative to the U.S. dollar may result in material changes to Viad s net equity position reported in its consolidated balance sheets.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Viad does not currently hedge its equity risk arising from the translation of foreign denominated assets and liabilities.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Viad had cumulative unrealized foreign currency translation gains recorded in stockholders equity of $39.0 million and $31.3 million as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P4_S2	During 2010 and 2009, unrealized foreign currency translation gains of $7.7 million and $25.1 million, respectively, were recorded in other comprehensive income.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P5_S0	In addition, for purposes of consolidation, the revenues, expenses, gains and losses related to Viad s foreign operations are translated into U.S. dollars at the average foreign exchange rates for the period.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P5_S1	As a result, Viad s consolidated results of operations are exposed to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates as the operating results of its foreign operations, when translated, may vary from period to period, even when the functional currency amounts have not changed.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P5_S2	Such fluctuations may adversely impact overall expected profitability and historical period to period comparisons.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Viad does not currently hedge its net earnings exposure arising from the translation of its foreign operating results.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P7_S0	As noted above, Viad primarily conducts its foreign operations in Canada and the United Kingdom.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P7_S1	The following table summarizes the effect of foreign exchange rate variances on segment operating results from Viad s Canadian and United Kingdom operations:
884219_11_ITEM7A_P8_S0	As the Canadian operations generated aggregate operating income in 2010, Viad s segment operating income has been favorably impacted by $1.1 million from the strengthening of the Canadian dollar relative to the U.S. dollar.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P8_S1	A hypothetical change of ten percent in the Canadian exchange rate would have resulted in a change to operating income of approximately $1.9 million.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P9_S0	As the United Kingdom operations generated aggregate operating income in 2010, Viad s segment operating income has been favorably impacted by $52,000 from the strengthening of the British pound relative to the U.S. dollar.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P9_S1	A hypothetical change of ten percent in the British pound exchange rate would have resulted in a change to operating income of approximately $656,000.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P10_S0	Viad is exposed to foreign exchange transaction risk as its foreign subsidiaries have certain revenue transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the respective subsidiary.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P10_S1	From time to time, Viad utilizes forward contracts to mitigate the impact on earnings related to these transactions due to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P10_S2	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, Viad did not have any significant foreign currency forward contracts outstanding.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P11_S0	Viad is exposed to short-term interest rate risk on certain of its debt obligations.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P11_S1	Viad currently does not use derivative financial instruments to hedge cash flows for such obligations.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P12_S0	As of December 31, 2010 Viad had variable rate debt outstanding of $4.5 million under the Credit Facility.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P12_S1	Interest payments related to Viad s variable rate debt outstanding are indexed to LIBOR.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P12_S2	Assuming a hypothetical adverse change in short term interest rates of 50 and 100 basis points, Viad s 2010 income from continuing operations before income taxes would have been lower by approximately $200,000 and $230,000, respectively.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P12_S3	See Note 9 of notes to consolidated financial statements.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P13_S0	Viad s subsidiaries have exposure to changing fuel prices.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P13_S1	Periodically, Brewster enters into futures contracts with an oil company to purchase two types of fuel and specifies the monthly total volume, by fuel product, to be purchased over the agreed upon term of the contract, which is generally no longer than one year.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P14_S0	The main objective of Viad s risk policy related to changing fuel prices is to reduce transaction exposure in order to mitigate the cash flow risk and protect profit margins.
884219_11_ITEM7A_P14_S1	There were no fuel contracts outstanding as of December 31, 2010 or 2009.
