884219_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	We operate through two main business groups:
884219_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	GES is a world-class live event service provider to some of the most visible and influential events and global brands.
884219_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	Pursuit is a collection of iconic natural and cultural destination travel experiences that enjoy perennial demand.
884219_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	GES accounted for 87% of our 2017 consolidated revenue and 51% of our 2017 consolidated segment operating income (1) .
884219_18_ITEM1_P3_S1	Pursuit accounted for 13% of our 2017 consolidated revenue and 49% of our 2017 consolidated segment operating income (1) .
884219_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	We define segment operating income as net income attributable to Viad before income (loss) from discontinued operations, corporate activities and eliminations, interest expense and interest income, income taxes, restructuring charges, impairment charges and recoveries, the reduction for income attributable to non-redeemable noncontrolling interest, and the addition for loss attributable to redeemable noncontrolling interest.
884219_18_ITEM1_P4_S1	Refer to Note 22 Segment Information of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this 2017 Form 10-K) for a reconciliation of segment operating income to the most directly comparable GAAP measure.
884219_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	GES is a global, full-service provider for live events that produces exhibitions, conferences, corporate events, and consumer events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P5_S1	GES offers a comprehensive range of live event services, from the design and production of compelling, immersive experiences that engage audiences and build brand awareness, to material handling, rigging, electrical, and other on-site event services.
884219_18_ITEM1_P5_S2	In addition, GES offers clients a full suite of audio-visual services from creative and technology to content and design, along with online tools powered by next generation technologies that help clients easily manage the complexities of their events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P5_S3	For nine years, GES National Servicenter has been certified under the J.D. Power and Associates Certified Call Center Program SM , and for eight consecutive years, Ad Age has recognized GES as one of the nation s largest experiential/event marketing agency networks.
884219_18_ITEM1_P5_S4	GES is included in Event Marketer magazine s IT List as one of the top 100 event agencies in the industry.
884219_18_ITEM1_P5_S5	GES clients include event organizers and corporate brand marketers.
884219_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	Event organizers schedule and run the event from start to finish.
884219_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	Corporate brand marketers include exhibitors and domestic and international corporations that want to promote their brands, services and innovations, feature new products, and build business relationships.
884219_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	GES serves corporate brand marketers when they exhibit at shows and when GES is engaged to manage their global exhibit program or produce their proprietary corporate events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	GES operates through two reportable business segments based on geography:
884219_18_ITEM1_P9_S0	GES U.S. has a leading position in the U.S. with full-service operations in every major exhibition market, including Las Vegas, Nevada; Chicago, Illinois; Orlando, Florida; New York, New York; and Los Angeles, California.
884219_18_ITEM1_P10_S0	GES International has operating facilities at many of the most active and popular international event destinations and venues, including seven cities in Canada, seven cities in the United Kingdom, two cities in Germany, two cities in the United Arab Emirates, two cities in the Netherlands, one city in Hong Kong, Switzerland, and Romania, and through these facilities offers full-service event operations across the United Kingdom, Europe, and the Middle East.
884219_18_ITEM1_P11_S0	Markets Served GES provides a full suite of services for event organizers and corporate brand marketers across four live event markets: Exhibitions, Conferences, Corporate Events, and Consumer Events (collectively, Live Events ).
884219_18_ITEM1_P12_S0	Facilitates business-to-business and business-to-consumer sales and marketing.
884219_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	May also include an expo or trade show to further facilitate attendee education and to facilitate business-to-business and business-to-consumer sales and marketing.
884219_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	Facilitates attendee education of sponsoring company s products or product ecosystem.
884219_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	Entertains, educates, or creates an experience, typically around a specific genre.
884219_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	Services Offered GES offers a comprehensive range of services and innovative technology, including Core Services, Event Technology, and Audio-Visual, to event organizers and corporate brand marketers.
884219_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	For Live Events, GES provides official contracting services and products to event organizers and corporate brand marketers.
884219_18_ITEM1_P17_S1	Contracting services and products are provided primarily to Exhibitions and to a lesser degree to Conferences, Corporate Events, and Consumer Events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	GES U.S. Core Services accounted for 57% of Viad s 2017 consolidated revenue and 61% of Viad s 2016 and 2015 consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1_P18_S1	GES International Core Services accounted for 19% of Viad s 2017 and 2016 consolidated revenue and 23% of Viad s 2015 consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	In general, GES provides the following exclusive and discretionary services and products to Live Event organizers and corporate brand marketers:
884219_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	Under various agreements with Live Events organizers, GES is the official services contractor with the exclusive right to provide certain services to exhibitors participating in a Live Event.
884219_18_ITEM1_P20_S1	This gives exhibitors a single point of contact to facilitate a timely, safe, and efficient move-in/out of a Live Event and to facilitate an organized, professional, during-show experience.
884219_18_ITEM1_P20_S2	GES also competes with other service providers to sell discretionary services to exhibitors.
884219_18_ITEM1_P20_S3	Discretionary services include comple te event program management, such as creative design, strategy, and planning to corporate brand marketers across all Live Events in which they participate.
884219_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	GES offers a comprehensive range of event technology services, including event accommodation solutions, registration and data analytics, and event management tools.
884219_18_ITEM1_P22_S0	GES U.S. offers end-to-end event accommodation services in North America.
884219_18_ITEM1_P22_S1	Event accommodations provide the unique potential to serve multiple Live Event participants through a single integrated service network.
884219_18_ITEM1_P22_S2	Event accommodations services include: Researching and selection of local hotels Negotiating and contracting Room block management Group reservation management Rate integrity and monitoring Marketing services On-site services Post-event reporting Registration and data analytics .
884219_18_ITEM1_P23_S0	GES provides event registration and data analytic services including: Registration and ticketing Lead management Reporting and analytics Web-based enterprise-wide application Software-as-a-service model or fully managed options Attendee engagement Digital collections Event management tools.
884219_18_ITEM1_P23_S1	GES provides event management services including: Online ordering capabilities Sponsorship management tools Content management systems Live Event tracking GES U.S. provides all three of the above event technology services which accounted for 2% of Viad s 2017 consolidated revenue and 3% of Viad s 2016 and 2015 consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1_P23_S2	GES International provides registration and data analytics and event management tools, which accounted for 1% of Viad s 2017, 2016, and 2015 consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1_P24_S0	GES offers a variety of high-impact multi-media services and technology across all Live Events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P24_S1	GES combines the science of innovative digital solutions with the latest audio-visual technology and superior service to create award-winning attendee engagements.
884219_18_ITEM1_P24_S2	GES expanded its audio-visual services through the 2016 acquisition of ON Event Services, LLC ( ON Services ), which enhances GES ability to gain market share in the Corporate Event markets in North America and enables GES to cross-sell its services and technology offerings.
884219_18_ITEM1_P24_S3	Audio-visual services include: Video and lighting production Digital studio services Entertainment services and talent coordination Projection mapping Computer rental and support GES U.S. audio-visual services accounted for 6% of Viad s 2017 consolidated revenue, 3% of Viad s 2016 consolidated revenue, and 1% of Viad s 2015 consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1_P24_S4	GES International audio-visual services accounted for 2% of Viad s 2017, 2016, and 2015 consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1_P25_S0	Seasonality and Show Rotation GES exhibition and event activity can vary significantly from quarter to quarter and year to year depending on the frequency and timing of shows: some shows are not held annually, and some shift between quarters.
884219_18_ITEM1_P25_S1	During 2017, GES U.S. reported its highest revenue during the first and second quarters.
884219_18_ITEM1_P25_S2	During 2016, GES U.S. reported its highest revenue during the second and third quarters.
884219_18_ITEM1_P25_S3	GES International generally reports its highest revenue during the second and fourth quarters.
884219_18_ITEM1_P25_S4	The following show rotation revenue metric refers to the net change in revenue from 2016 to 2017 due to show movement between quarters and years.
884219_18_ITEM1_P26_S0	Show rotation refers to shows that occur less frequently than annually, as well as annual shows that shift quarters from one year to the next.
884219_18_ITEM1_P27_S0	Competition In the Live Events industry, GES generally competes across all classes of services and all markets on the basis of discernible differences, value, quality, price, convenience, and service.
884219_18_ITEM1_P27_S1	GES has a competitive advantage through its worldwide network of resources, history of serving as an extension of clients teams, experienced and knowledgeable personnel, client-focus, creativity, reliable execution, proprietary technology platforms, and financial strength.
884219_18_ITEM1_P28_S0	All known U.S. competitors and most international competitors are privately held companies that provide limited public information regarding their operations.
884219_18_ITEM1_P28_S1	GES primary competitor within its Core Services is The Freeman Company (a privately-held, U.S.-headquartered company); however, there is substantial competition from a large number of service providers in GES other service offerings.
884219_18_ITEM1_P29_S0	Growth Strategy GES is committed to become the preferred global, full-service provider for Live Events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P29_S1	GES holds a leading market position in Exhibitions and is pursuing a focused and disciplined growth strategy with the goal of expanding its market share in the currently under-penetrated Conferences, Corporate Events, and Consumer Events markets.
884219_18_ITEM1_P29_S2	GES has uniquely combined the art of high-impact creativity, service, and expertise with the science of easy-to-use technology, strategy, and worldwide logistics to help clients gain a greater return from their events and enhance the exhibitor experience.
884219_18_ITEM1_P30_S0	Leverage global capabilities and large customer base to drive continued growth in new services and other Live Events.
884219_18_ITEM1_P31_S0	Growth of adjacent services to create a unique and integrated offering to deepen client relationships, expand client base, and increase share of total event spend.
884219_18_ITEM1_P32_S0	Penetration into other live events to extend industry leadership and leverage capabilities.
884219_18_ITEM1_P33_S0	With our recent acquisitions, GES made significant progress toward creating the most comprehensive suite of services for the Live Events industry, which enhanced overall competitiveness, facilitated growth in under-penetrated areas, and formed a basis for a data platform.
884219_18_ITEM1_P33_S1	We continue to pursue opportunities to acquire businesses with proven products and services that complement, enhance, or expand current businesses or offer growth opportunities.
884219_18_ITEM1_P34_S0	In March 2017, we completed the acquisition of the Poken event engagement technology, a leading cloud-based visitor engagement and measurement platform.
884219_18_ITEM1_P34_S1	The Poken platform offers a seamless ecosystem of tools that enable digital document collection (through its patented Touch and Glow technology), visitor-to-visitor engagement, gamification, and metrics reporting.

884219_18_ITEM1_P37_S0	Pursuit is a collection of iconic natural and cultural destination travel experiences in North America that showcase the best of Banff, Jasper, Waterton Lakes, Glacier, Denali, and Kenai Fjords National Parks, and Vancouver, Canada.
884219_18_ITEM1_P37_S1	Through Pursuit s collection of unique hotels and lodges, world-class recreational attractions, and ground transportation services, it connects guests to iconic places through unforgettable, inspiring experiences.

884219_18_ITEM1_P39_S1	The Alaska Collection also provides food and beverage services and retail operations.

884219_18_ITEM1_P40_S1	Glacier Park, Inc. is an 80% owned subsidiary of ours.
884219_18_ITEM1_P41_S0	FlyOver Canada, located in Vancouver, British Columbia, is a recreational attraction that provides a virtual flight ride experience that combines motion seating, spectacular media, and visual effects including wind, scents, and mist to give the unforgettable experience of flying across Canada.

884219_18_ITEM1_P78_S0	Competition Pursuit generally competes on the basis of location, uniqueness of facilities, service, quality, and price.
884219_18_ITEM1_P78_S1	Competition exists both locally and regionally across all four lines of business.
884219_18_ITEM1_P79_S0	The hospitality business has a large number of competitors and competes for leisure travelers (both individual and tour groups) across the United States and Canada.
884219_18_ITEM1_P79_S1	Pursuit s competitive advantage is its distinctive attractions and iconic destinations.
884219_18_ITEM1_P80_S0	Growth Strategy Pursuit remains focused on delivering inspiring and unforgettable experiences in iconic locations while growing and enhancing its unique portfolio of integrated tourism assets through its Refresh-Build-Buy growth initiatives.
884219_18_ITEM1_P81_S0	Refresh assets and processes to optimize market position and maximize returns.
884219_18_ITEM1_P82_S0	Build new assets that create new revenue streams with economies of scale and scope.
884219_18_ITEM1_P83_S0	Buy strategic assets that drive economies of scale and scope with strong returns.
884219_18_ITEM1_P84_S0	We continue to search for opportunities to acquire or to build high return tourism assets in iconic natural and cultural destinations that enjoy perennial demand, bring meaningful scale and market share, and offer cross-selling advantages with a combination of attractions and hotels.
884219_18_ITEM1_P85_S0	On December 29, 2016, the Mount Royal Hotel was damaged by fire and closed.
884219_18_ITEM1_P85_S1	In July 2017, we resolved our property and business interruption insurance claims related to the fire for $36.3 million.
884219_18_ITEM1_P85_S2	We allocated $2.2 million to an insurance receivable, $29.3 million was recorded as an impairment recovery (partially offset by impairment charges of $0.2 million) related to construction costs to re-open the hotel, $2.5 million was recorded as a business interruption gain for the recovery of lost profits, $1.3 million was recorded as contra-expense to offset non-capitalizable costs incurred, and the remaining $1.0 million was recorded as deferred revenue that will be recognized over the periods the business interruption losses are actually incurred.

884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Completed acquisitions may not perform as anticipated or be integrated as planned.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	We regularly evaluate and pursue opportunities to acquire businesses that complement, enhance, or expand our current business, or offer growth opportunities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Our acquired businesses might not meet our financial and non-financial expectations or yield anticipated benefits.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Our success depends, in part, on our ability to conform controls, policies and procedures, and business cultures; consolidate and streamline operations and infrastructures; identify and eliminate redundant and underperforming operations and assets; manage inefficiencies associated with integration of operations; and retain the acquired business key personnel and customers.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Moreover, our acquisition activity potentially increases our debt, subjects us to new regulatory requirements, distracts our senior management and employees, and exposes us to unknown liabilities or contingencies that we fail to, or are unable to identify prior to closing.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S5	If our acquisitions cause us to make changes to our business strategy or if external conditions adversely affect our business operations, we may also be required to record an impairment charge to goodwill or intangible assets.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S6	Any of these risks could materially and adversely affect our business, product and service sales, financial condition, and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S7	We depend on our large exhibition event clients to renew their service contracts and on our exclusive right to provide those services.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S8	During 2017, no single client accounted for more than 6% of our consolidated revenue.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S9	However, GES has a number of large exhibition event organizers and large customer accounts.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S10	If any of these large clients do not renew their service contracts, our results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S11	Moreover, when event organizers hire GES as the official services contractor, they also grant GES an exclusive right to perform electrical, plumbing services, and other services (the Event Services ) at the exhibition facility.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S12	However, exhibition facilities are under increasing financial pressure to in-source Event Services (either by performing the services themselves or by hiring a separate service provider) as a result of conditions generally affecting their industry, such as an increased supply of exhibition space.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P0_S13	If a large number of exhibition facilities choose to in-source Event Services, GES will lose the ability to provide Event Services despite being hired as the official services contractor, and our results of operations could be materially and adversely affected.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Our GES business is heavily focused on client relationships, and, specifically, on having close collaboration and interaction with our clients.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P1_S1	To be successful, our account team must be able to understand a client s desires and expectations in order to provide top-quality service.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P1_S2	If we lose a key member of our account team, we could also lose customers and our results of operations could be materially and adversely affected.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We operate in highly competitive industries.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We are engaged in a number of highly competitive industries.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Competition in the Live Events industry and the exhibits and experiential environments industries is driven by price and service quality, among other factors.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P3_S2	To the extent competitors seek to gain or retain their market presence through aggressive underpricing strategies, we may be required to lower our prices and rates to avoid the loss of related business, thereby adversely affecting our results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P3_S3	In addition, if we are unable to anticipate and respond as effectively as competitors to changing business conditions, including new technologies and business models, we could lose market share to our competitors.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Our inability to meet the challenges presented by the competitive environment could materially and adversely affect our results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Travel industry disruptions, particularly those affecting the hotel and airline industries, could adversely affect our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Our business de pends largely on the ability and willingness of people, whether exhibitors, exhibition attendees, or others, to travel.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Factors adversely affecting the travel industry, and particularly the airline and hotel industries, generally also adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Factors that could adversely affect the travel industry include high or rising fuel prices, increased security and passport requirements, weather conditions, airline accidents, and international political instability and hostilities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P4_S4	Any of these factors, or other unexpected events that affect the availability and pricing of air travel and accommodations, could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Transportation disruptions and increases in transportation costs could adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	GES relies on independent transportation carriers to send materials and exhibits to and from exhibition, warehouse, and customer facilities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S1	If our customers and suppliers are unable to secure the services of those independent transportation carriers at favorable rates, it could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S2	In addition, disruption of transportation services due to weather-related problems, labor strikes, lockouts, or other events could adversely affect our ability to supply services to customers and could cause the cancellation of exhibitions, which could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S3	The seasonality of our business makes us particularly sensitive to adverse events during peak periods.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S4	Our GES exhibition and event activity varies significantly because it is based on the frequency and timing of shows, many of which are not held each year and which may shift between quarters.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S5	The peak activity for our Pursuit business is during the summer months.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S6	Consequently, during 2017, 87% of Pursuit s revenue was earned in the second and third quarters.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S7	If adverse events or conditions occur during these peak periods our results of operations could be materially and adversely affected.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S8	Terrorist attacks, natural disasters, or other catastrophic events could negatively affect our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S9	The occurrence of catastrophic events ranging from natural disasters (such as hurricanes, fires, and floods), health epidemics or pandemics, acts of war or terrorism, accidents involving our travel offerings or experiences, or the prospect of these events could disrupt our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S10	Such catastrophic events could have a negative impact on GES production facilities, preventing us from timely completing exhibit fabrication and other projects for customers.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S11	They could also cause a cancellation of exhibitions and other events held in public venues or disrupt the services we provide to our customers at convention centers, exhibition halls, hotels, and other public venues.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S12	Such catastrophic events could also have an adverse impact on Pursuit, which is heavily dependent on the ability and willingness of its guests to travel.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S13	Pursuit guests tend to delay or postpone vacations if natural conditions differ from those that typically prevail at competing lodges, resorts and attractions, and catastrophic events could impede the guests ability to travel, interrupt our business operations, and/or cause damage to our properties.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S14	In addition, unfavorable media attention, or negative publicity, in the wake of a catastrophic event could damage our reputation or reduce the demand for our services.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P6_S15	If the conditions arising from such events persist or worsen, they could materially and adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We are vulnerable to deterioration in general economic conditions.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Our business is sensitive to fluctuations in general economic conditions that affect the cost of materials and operating supplies.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P7_S2	The success of our GES business largely depends on the number of exhibitions held, the size of exhibitors marketing expenditures, and on the strength of particular industries in which exhibitors operate.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P7_S3	The number and size of exhibitions generally decrease when the economy weakens.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P7_S4	We also suffer from reduced spending for our services because many exhibitors marketing budgets are partly discretionary, and are frequently among the first expenditures reduced when economic conditions deteriorate.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P7_S5	Consequently, marketing expenditures often are not increased until economic conditions improve.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Revenue from our Pursuit operation depends largely on the amount of disposable income that consumers have available for travel and vacations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	This amount decreases during periods of weak general economic conditions.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Any of these risks could materially and adversely affect our business, product sales, financial condition, and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Recent U.S. tax legislation may materially and adversely affect our financial condition, results of operations, and cash flows.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the Tax Act ), enacted in late 2017, makes significant changes to U.S. tax laws and includes numerous provisions that could affect our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P9_S2	For instance, as a result of lower corporate tax rates, the Tax Act tends to reduce both the value of deferred tax assets and the amount of deferred tax liabilities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P9_S3	It also limits interest rate deductions and the amount of net operating losses that can be used each year and alters the expensing of capital expenditures.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Other provisions have tax consequences for our international operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	The Tax Act is unclear in certain respects and will require interpretations and implementing regulations by the Internal Revenue Service, as well as state tax authorities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The Tax Act could also be subject to amendments and technical corrections, any of which could lessen or increase the adverse impacts on our business operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P11_S2	The accounting treatment of these tax law changes is complex, and some of the changes may affect both current and future periods.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Others will primarily affect future periods.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	As we have discussed elsewhere in this Report on Form 10-K, we believe our analysis and computations of the tax effects of the Tax Act on financial results is substantially, but not entirely, complete.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Consistent with guidance from the SEC, our financial statements reflect our estimates of the tax effects of the Tax Act on our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	provisional and may be adjusted prior to the end of 2018.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Any such adjustments could affect our current or future financial statements, or both.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P13_S2	We continue to examine the impact of this tax reform legislation, a nd as its overall impact is uncertain, we note that the Tax Act could adversely affect our business and financial condition.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We are subject to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We have operations outside of the U.S. primarily in Canada, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Germany, and to a lesser extent, in certain other countries.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S2	During 2017, GES International and Pursuit s international operations accounted for approximately 30% of our consolidated revenue and 58% of our segment operating income.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S3	Consequently, a significant portion of our business is exposed to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Our financial results and capital ratios are sensitive to movements in currency exchange rates because a large portion of our assets, liabilities, revenue, and expenses must be translated into U.S. dollars for reporting purposes.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S5	The unrealized gains or losses resulting from the currency translation are included as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in our consolidated balance sheets.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P14_S6	As a result, significant fluctuations in currency exchange rates could result in material changes to the net equity position we report in our consolidated balance sheets.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We do not currently hedge equity risk arising from the translation of non-U.S. denominated assets and liabilities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Our participation in multi-employer pension plans could substantially increase our pension costs.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We sponsor a number of defined benefit plans for our U.S. and Canada-based employees.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S3	We are obligated to contribute to multi-employer pension plans under collective-bargaining agreements covering our union-represented employees.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S4	We contributed $26.6 million in 2017 and $25.8 million in 2016 to those multi-employer pension plans.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S5	These multi-employer plans are managed by third-party boards of trustees.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S6	Based upon the information we receive from plan administrators, we believe that several of those multi-employer plans are underfunded.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S7	The Pension Protection Act of 2006 requires us to reduce the underfunded status over defined time periods.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S8	Moreover, we would be required to make additional payments of our proportionate share of a plan s unfunded vested liabilities if a plan terminates, or other contributing employers withdraw, due to insolvency or other reasons, or if we voluntarily withdraw from a plan.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S9	At this time, we cannot determine with any certainty the amount of additional funding, if any, we could be required to make to those plans.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S10	However, significant plan contribution increases, could materially and adversely affect our consolidated financial condition, results of operations, and cash flows.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P15_S11	Refer to Note 17 Pension and Postretirement Benefits of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this 2017 Form 10-K) for further information.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Union-represented labor increases our risk of higher labor costs and work stoppages.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S1	A significant portion of our employees are unionized.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S2	We have approximately 100 collective-bargaining agreements, and we are required to renegotiate approximately one-third of those each year.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S3	If we increase wages or benefits as a result of labor negotiations, either our operating margins will suffer, or we could increase the cost of our services to our customers, which could lead those customers to turn to other vendors with lower prices.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S4	Either event could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S5	Additionally, if we are unable to reach an agreement with a union during the collective-bargaining process, the union may strike or carry out other types of work stoppages.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P16_S6	If that happens, we might be unable to find substitute workers with the necessary skills to perform many of the services, or we may incur additional costs to do so, both of which could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We are vulnerable to cybersecurity attacks and threats.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P17_S1	We regularly collect and process credit, financial, and other personal, sensitive, and confidential information from individuals and entities who attend or participate in events and exhibitions that we produce, or who visit our attractions and other offerings.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P17_S2	In addition, our devices, servers, computer systems, and business systems are vulnerable to cybersecurity risk, including cyberattacks, or we may be the target of email scams that attempt to acquire personal information and company assets.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Despite our efforts to protect ourselves with insurance, and create security barriers to such threats, including regularly reviewing our systems for vulnerabilities and continually updating our protections, we might not be able to entirely mitigate these risks.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P17_S4	Our failure to effectively prevent, detect, and recover from the increasing number and sophistication of information security threats could lead to business interruptions, delays or loss of critical data, misuse, modification, or destruction of information, including trade secrets and confidential business information, reputational damage, and third-party claims, any of which could adversely and materially affect our results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P17_S5	Laws and regulations relating to the handling of personal data could result in increased costs, legal claims, or fines.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	We store and process personally identifiable information from our customers, employees, and third parties with whom we have business relationships.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P18_S1	Legal requirements relating to the collection, storage, handling, and transfer of personal data continue to evolve and could lead to burdensome or inconsistent requirements affecting the location and movement of our customer and internal employee data as well as the management of the data.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P18_S2	For example, in July 2016, the EU and the U.S. agreed on a mechanism for companies to transfer data from EU member states to the U.S.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P18_S3	This framework, called the Privacy Shield, is intended to address shortcomings identified by the European Court of Justice in a predecessor mechanism.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The Privacy Shield and other mechanisms are currently subject to challenges in European courts, which may lead to uncertainty about the legal basis for data transfers across the Atlantic.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Also, in May 2018, the EU s new General Data Protection Regul ation (GDPR) will replace the existing EU Data Protection Directive, and it will have a significant impact on how businesses can collect and process the personal data of EU individuals.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P19_S2	The GDPR includes a requirement for businesses to self-report personal data breaches to the relevant supervisory authority and, under certain circumstances, to the affected data subjects.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P19_S3	It also gives additional rights to individuals whose data are processed, including the right to erasure (also commonly known as the righ t to be forgotten) by having their records erased and the right to data portability.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Compliance with the myriad requirements could involve changes in our services, business practices, or internal systems that could likely increase our costs, lower revenue, reduce efficiency, or make it more difficult to compete with Non-U.S.-based firms.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Our failure to comply with existing or new rules could result in significant penalties or orders to stop the alleged noncompliant activity, litigation, adverse publicity, o r could cause our customers to lose trust in our services .
884219_18_ITEM1A_P20_S2	In addition, if the third parties we work with violate applicable laws, contractual obligations, or suffer a security breach, those violations could also put us in breach of our obligations under p rivacy laws and regulations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Any of these risks could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	New capital projects may not be commercially successful.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	From time to time, we pursue capital projects, such as our current efforts to upgrade some of our Pursuit offerings in order to seize opportunities that complement, enhance, and expand our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Capital projects are subject to a number of risks, including unanticipated delays, cost overruns, and the failure to achieve established financial and strategic goals, as well as additional risks specific to a project.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P22_S1	The occurrence of any of these events could prevent a new capital project from performing in accordance with our commercial expectations and could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Show rotation affects our profitability and makes comparisons between periods difficult.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	GES results are largely dependent upon the frequency, timing, and location of exhibitions and events.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Some large exhibitions are not held annually (they may be held once every two or three years or longer) or may be held at different times of year from when they were previously held.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P24_S2	In addition, the same exhibition may change locations from year to year resulting in lower margins if the exhibition shifts to a higher-cost location.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	Any of these factors could cause our results of operations to fluctuate significantly from quarter to quarter or from year to year, making periodic comparisons difficult.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P24_S4	The United Kingdom s exit from the European Union could adversely affect our business.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P24_S5	We operate substantial parts of our EU businesses from U.K-based entities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	The June 23, 2016 U.K. referendum resulted in a determination that the U.K. should exit the EU.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P25_S1	In March 2017, the U.K. government initiated the exit process under Article 50 of the Treaty of the EU, commencing a period of up to two years for the United Kingdom and the other EU member states to negotiate the terms of the withdrawal.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P25_S2	The uncertainty surrounding the timing, terms and consequences of the U.K. s exit could adversely impact customer and investor confidence, result in additional market volatility and adversely affect our businesses and our results of operations and financial condition.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Once the U.K. exits from the EU, the regulatory and legal environment that would then govern our U.K. operations will depend on, in certain respects, the nature of the arrangements agreed to between the U.K., the EU, and other trading partners.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P26_S1	It is likely that changes to our legal entity structure and operations in Europe will be required as a result of these arrangements, which might result in a less efficient operating model across our European legal entities.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Liabilities relating to prior and discontinued operations may adversely affect our results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We, and our predecessors, have a corporate history spanning over eight decades and involving approximately 2,400 previous subsidiaries in diverse businesses, such as the manufacturing of locomotives, buses, industrial chemicals, fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, leather, textiles, food, and fresh meats.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Some of those businesses used raw materials that have been, and may continue to be, subject to litigation.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Moreover, some of the raw materials used and the waste produced by those businesses have been and are the subject of U.S. federal and state environmental regulations, including laws enacted under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act, or its state law counterparts.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P28_S3	In addition, we may incur other liabilities, resulting from indemnification claims involving previously sold subsidiaries, as well as from past operations of predecessors or their subsidiaries.
884219_18_ITEM1A_P28_S4	Although we believe we have adequate reserves and sufficient insurance coverage to cover those future liabilities, future events or proceedings could contradict with current assumptions, which could cause reserves or insurance to become inadequate and, ultimately, materially and adversely affect our results of operations.

884219_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	Overview We are an international experiential services company with operations in the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, continental Europe, and the United Arab Emirates.
884219_18_ITEM7_P0_S1	We are committed to providing unforgettable experiences to our clients and guests.
884219_18_ITEM7_P0_S2	We operate through three reportable business segments: GES U.S., GES International, (collectively, GES ), and Pursuit.
884219_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	GES is a global, full-service provider for live events that produces exhibitions, conferences, corporate events, and consumer events.
884219_18_ITEM7_P1_S1	GES offers a comprehensive range of live event services and a full suite of audio-visual services from creative and technology to content and design, along with online tools powered by next generation technologies that help clients easily manage the complexities of their events.
884219_18_ITEM7_P2_S0	Pursuit is a collection of iconic natural and cultural destination travel experiences that enjoy perennial demand.
884219_18_ITEM7_P2_S1	Pursuit offers guests distinctive and world renowned experiences through its collection of unique hotels and lodges, world-class recreational attractions, and ground transportation services.
884219_18_ITEM7_P3_S0	Total revenue increased $102.0 million or 8.5%, mainly due to the incremental revenue from the ON Services and FlyOver Canada acquisitions, and to a lesser degree, the Poken, and CATC acquisitions, of $52.6 million and underlying growth at GES and Pursuit, offset in part by negative show rotation of approximately $8 million and an unfavorable foreign exchange impact of $5.6 million.

884219_18_ITEM7_P20_S0	2018 Outlook Although GES has a diversified revenue base and long-term contracts for future shows, its revenue is affected by general economic and industry-specific conditions.
884219_18_ITEM7_P20_S1	The prospects for individual shows tend to be driven by the success of the industry related to those shows.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S0	In general, the exhibition and event industry is experiencing modest growth.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S1	For 2018, we expect GES revenue will be up slightly from 2017.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S2	Show rotation is expected to have a net negative impact on GES revenue of approximately $40 million compared to 2017.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S3	We expect GES U.S. base same-show revenue to increase at a mid-single digit rate.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S4	We anticipate a favorable FX Impact of approximately $18 million on GES 2018 full year revenue and approximately $0.5 million on GES segment operating income.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S5	The expected FX Impact assumes that the U.S. dollar to the British pound exchange rate will be $1.39 and the U.S. dollar to the Canadian dollar exchange rate will be $0.81 during 2018.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S6	For more information about segment operating income, see the Non-GAAP Measures section of this MD A. We are executing a strategic growth plan to position GES as the preferred global, full-service provider for Live Events, with further reach to corporate events, consumer events, conferences, and exhibitions.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S7	To support this strategy, since 2014, we have acquired two leading audio-visual production businesses and four leading event technology businesses that complement, enhance, and expand our current business and offer higher-margin growth opportunities.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S8	We continue to pursue additional opportunities to acquire businesses with proven products and services to create the most comprehensive suite of services for the Live Events industry.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S9	During 2018, we intend to make selective investments in additional resources to capitalize on continued growth opportunities in under-penetrated categories of Live Events, such as corporate events and consumer events, and in cross-selling new services.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S10	Additionally, we remain focused on improving GES profitability through continued efforts to effectively manage labor costs by driving productivity gains through rigorous and strategic pre-show planning and on-site labor management that reduces the ratio of labor costs to revenue.
884219_18_ITEM7_P21_S11	Improving this metric is our top priority as we continue to develop and enhance tools to support and systematize show site labor planning, measurement, and benchmarking.

884219_18_ITEM7_P35_S0	Performance Measures We use the following key business metrics, common in the hospitality industry, to evaluate Pursuit s hospitality business:
884219_18_ITEM7_P36_S0	RevPAR is calculated as total rooms revenue divided by the total number of room nights available for all comparable Pursuit hospitality properties during the period.
884219_18_ITEM7_P36_S1	Total rooms revenue does not include non-rooms revenue, which consists of ancillary revenue generated by hospitality properties, such as food and beverage and retail revenue.
884219_18_ITEM7_P37_S0	RevPAR measures the period-over-period change in rooms revenue for comparable hospitality properties.
884219_18_ITEM7_P37_S1	RevPAR is affected by average daily rate and occupancy, which have different implications on profitability.
884219_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	ADR is calculated as total rooms revenue divided by the total number of room nights sold for all comparable Pursuit hospitality properties during the period.
884219_18_ITEM7_P38_S1	ADR is used to assess the pricing levels that the hospitality properties are able to generate.
884219_18_ITEM7_P38_S2	Increases in ADR at hospitality properties lead to increases in rooms revenue with no substantial effect on variable costs, therefore having a greater impact on margins than increases in occupancy.
884219_18_ITEM7_P39_S0	Occupancy is calculated as the total number of room nights sold divided by the total number of room nights available for all comparable Pursuit hospitality properties during the period.
884219_18_ITEM7_P40_S0	Occupancy measures the utilization of the available capacity at the hospitality properties.
884219_18_ITEM7_P40_S1	Increases in occupancy result in increases in rooms revenue and additional variable operating costs (including housekeeping services, utilities, and room amenity costs), as well as increased ancillary non-rooms revenue (including food and beverage and retail revenue).
884219_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	We evaluate the performance of Pursuit s attractions business utilizing the number of passengers and total attractions revenue per passenger.
884219_18_ITEM7_P41_S1	The number of passengers allows us to assess the volume of visitor activity at each attraction during the period.
884219_18_ITEM7_P41_S2	Total attractions revenue per passenger is calculated as total attractions revenue divided by the total number of passengers at all Pursuit attractions during the period.
884219_18_ITEM7_P41_S3	Total attractions revenue includes ticket sales and ancillary revenue generated by attractions, such as food and beverage and retail revenue.
884219_18_ITEM7_P41_S4	Total attractions revenue per passenger measures the total spend per visitor that attraction properties are able to capture, which is important to the profitability of the attractions business.

884219_18_ITEM7_P45_S6	Accordingly, the strengthening or weakening of the Canadian dollar, relative to other currencies, could affect customer volumes and the results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P45_S7	Additionally, Pursuit is affected by consumer discretionary spending on tourism activities.

884219_18_ITEM7_P65_S3	The consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP.
884219_18_ITEM7_P65_S4	We are required to make estimates and assumptions that affect our reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, and expenses.
884219_18_ITEM7_P65_S5	Critical accounting policies are those policies that are most important to the portrayal of our financial position and results of operations, and that require us to make the most difficult and subjective judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates of matters that are inherently uncertain.
884219_18_ITEM7_P65_S6	We identified and discussed with our audit committee the following critical accounting policies and estimates and the methodology and disclosures related to those estimates:
884219_18_ITEM7_P66_S0	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets Goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are not amortized, but instead are tested for impairment at least annually.
884219_18_ITEM7_P66_S1	Intangible assets with finite lives are amortized over their respective estimated useful lives and are reviewed for impairment if an event occurs or circumstances change that would indicate the intangible asset s carrying value may not be recover able.
884219_18_ITEM7_P66_S2	Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level on an annual basis as of October 31, and between annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that would more-likely-than-not reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying value.
884219_18_ITEM7_P66_S3	Our reporting units are defined, and goodwill is tested, at either an operating segment level or at the component level of an operating segment, depending on various factors including the internal reporting structure of the operating segment, the level of integration among components, the sharing of assets and other resources among components, and the benefits and likely recoverability of goodwill by the component s operations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P67_S0	GES U.S. goodwill is assigned to, and tested at, the operating segment level (all GES domestic operations).
884219_18_ITEM7_P67_S1	GES International goodwill is assigned to and tested based on the segment s geographical operations (GES Europe, Middle East, and Asia ( GES EMEA ) and GES Canada).
884219_18_ITEM7_P67_S2	Pursuit impairment testing is performed at the reporting unit level (Banff Jasper Collection, the Alaska Collection, the Glacier Park Collection, and FlyOver).
884219_18_ITEM7_P67_S3	For purposes of goodwill impairment testing, we use a discounted expected future cash flow methodology (income approach) to estimate the fair value of our reporting units.
884219_18_ITEM7_P67_S4	The estimates and assumptions regarding expected future cash flows, discount rates, and terminal values require considerable judgment and are based on market conditions, financial forecasts, industry trends, and historical experience.
884219_18_ITEM7_P67_S5	The most critical assumptions and estimates in determining the estimated fair value of our reporting units relate to the amounts and timing of expected future cash flows for each reporting unit and the reporting unit cost of capital (discount rate) applied to those cash flows.
884219_18_ITEM7_P68_S0	We estimate the assumed reporting unit cost of capital rates (discount rates) using a build-up method based on the perceived risk associated with the cash flows pertaining to the specific reporting unit.
884219_18_ITEM7_P68_S1	In order to assess the reasonableness of our fair value estimates, we perform a reconciliation of the aggregate fair values of our reporting units to our market capitalization.
884219_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	As noted above, the estimates and assumptions regarding expected future cash flows, discount rates, and terminal values require considerable judgment and are based on market conditions, financial forecasts, industry trends, and historical experience.
884219_18_ITEM7_P69_S1	These estimates have inherent uncertainties, and different assumptions could lead to materially different results.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S0	As of December 31, 2017, our aggregate goodwill was $270.6 million.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S1	As a result of our most recent impairment analysis performed as of October 31, 2017, the excess of the estimated fair value over the carrying value for each of our reporting units (expressed as a percentage of the carrying amounts) under step one of the impairment test for GES U.S. was 134%, GES EMEA was 214%, GES Canada was 164%, Banff Jasper Collection was 147%, the Alaska Collection was 99%, the Glacier Park Collection was 16%, and FlyOver was 29%.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S2	Significant reductions in our expected future revenue, operating income, or cash flow forecasts and projections, or an increase in a reporting unit s cost of capital, could trigger additional goodwill impairment testing, which may result in impairment charges.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S3	If an impairment indicator related to intangible assets is identified, or if other circumstances indicate an impairment may exist, we perform an assessment to determine if an impairment loss should be recognized.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S4	This assessment includes a recoverability test to identify if the expected future undiscounted cash flows are less than the carrying value of the related assets.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S5	If the results of the recoverability test indicate that expected future undiscounted cash flows are less than the carrying value of the related assets, we perform a measurement of impairment and we recognize any carrying amount in excess of fair value as an impairment.
884219_18_ITEM7_P70_S6	We periodically evaluate the continued recoverability of intangible assets which were previously evaluated due to an impairment indicator to determine if remeasurement is necessary.
884219_18_ITEM7_P71_S0	Income taxes We are required to estimate and record provisions for income taxes in each of the jurisdictions in which we operate.
884219_18_ITEM7_P71_S1	Accordingly, we must estimate our actual current income tax liability, and assess temporary differences arising from the treatment of items for tax purposes, as compared to the treatment for accounting purposes.
884219_18_ITEM7_P71_S2	These differences result in deferred tax assets and liabilities which are included in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
884219_18_ITEM7_P71_S3	We use significant judgment in forming conclusions regarding the recoverability of our deferred tax assets and evaluate all available positive and negative evidence to determine if it is more-likely-than-not that the deferred tax assets will be realized.
884219_18_ITEM7_P72_S0	To the extent recovery does not appear likely, a valuation allowance must be recorded.
884219_18_ITEM7_P73_S0	We had gross deferred tax assets of $38.1 million as of December 31, 2017 and $58.3 million as of December 31, 2016, which includes the remeasurement due to the reduction in the U.S. tax rate from 35% to 21% resulting in an $8.0 million reduction in the 2017 gross deferred tax assets.
884219_18_ITEM7_P73_S1	These deferred tax assets reflect the expected future tax benefits to be realized upon reversal of deductible temporary differences, and the utilization of net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S0	While we believe that the deferred tax assets, net of existing valuation allowances, will be utilized in future periods, there are inherent uncertaintie s regarding the ultimate realization of these assets.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S1	It is possible that the relative weight of positive and negative evidence regarding the realization of deferred tax assets may change, which could result in a material increase or decrease in our valuat ion allowance.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S2	Such a change could result in a material increase or decrease to income tax expense in the period the assessment was made.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S3	Due to the enactment of the Tax Act and the transition to a territorial tax system, we recognized $6.9 million of current federal tax expense and $1.2 million of current state tax expense for the mandatory deemed repatriation of our estimated unremitted earnings as of December 31, 2017.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S4	With the transition to a territorial tax system, future dividends will be fully deductible for federal tax purposes, however they may be taxable at the state level.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S5	We have not recorded deferred taxes on the incremental additional state taxes or withholding taxes on dividends from our foreign subsidiaries as we intend to reinvest those earnings in our foreign operations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P74_S6	We record uncertain tax positions on the basis of a two-step process: first we determine whether it is more-likely-than-not that the tax positions will be sustained on the basis of the technical merits of the position; and if so, we recognize the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50% likely to be realized upon ultimate settlement with the related tax authority.
884219_18_ITEM7_P75_S0	Pension and postretirement benefits Our pension plans use traditional defined benefit formulas based on years of service and final average compensation.
884219_18_ITEM7_P75_S1	Funding policies provide that payments to defined benefit pension trusts shall be at least equal to the minimum funding required by applicable regulations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P75_S2	We presently anticipate contributing $1.1 million to our funded pension plans and $1.0 million to our unfunded pension plans in 2018.
884219_18_ITEM7_P76_S0	We have defined benefit postretirement plans that provide medical and life insurance for certain eligible employees, retirees, and dependents.
884219_18_ITEM7_P76_S1	The related postretirement benefit liabilities are recognized over the employees service period.
884219_18_ITEM7_P76_S2	In addition, we retain the obligations for these benefits for retirees of certain sold businesses.
884219_18_ITEM7_P76_S3	While the plans have no funding requirements, we expect to contribute $1.1 million to the plans in 2018.
884219_18_ITEM7_P77_S0	The discount rates used in determining future pension and postretirement benefit obligations are based on rates determined by actuarial analysis and management review, and reflect the estimated rates of return on a high-quality, hypothetical bond portfolio whose cash flows match the timing and amounts of expected benefit payments.
884219_18_ITEM7_P77_S1	Refer to Note 17 Pension and Postretirement Benefits of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this 2017 Form 10-K) for further information.
884219_18_ITEM7_P78_S0	Share-based compensation We grant share-based compensation awards to our officers, directors, and certain key employees pursuant to the 2017 Viad Corp Omnibus Incentive Plan, which has a 10-year life and provides for the following types of awards: (a) incentive and non-qualified stock options; (b) restricted stock and restricted stock units; (c) performance units or performance shares; (d) stock appreciation rights; (e) cash-based awards; and (f) certain other stock-based awards.
884219_18_ITEM7_P78_S1	Share-based compensation expense recognized in the consolidated financial statements was $11.0 million in 2017, $8.0 million in 2016, and $3.8 million in 2015, and the total tax benefits related to such costs were $4.1 million in 2017, $3.0 million in 2016, and $1.5 million in 2016.
884219_18_ITEM7_P78_S2	No share-based compensation costs were capitalized during 2017, 2016, or 2015.
884219_18_ITEM7_P79_S0	The fair value of restricted stock awards is based on our stock price on the date of grant.
884219_18_ITEM7_P79_S1	Liability-based awards are recorded at estimated fair value, based on the number of units expected to vest and the level of achievement of predefined performance goals, where applicable, and are remeasured on each balance sheet date based on our stock price, and the Monte Carlo simulation model, until the time of settlement.
884219_18_ITEM7_P80_S0	The Monte Carlo simulation requires the use of a number of assumptions, including historical volatility and correlation of the price of our stock and the price of the common shares of a comparator group, a risk-free rate of return, and an expected term.
884219_18_ITEM7_P81_S0	Equity-based awards (including performance units) are recorded at estimated fair value, based on the number of units expected to vest and the level of achievement of predefined performance goals, until the time of settlement.
884219_18_ITEM7_P82_S0	We use the Black-Scholes option pricing model and key assumptions to determine the fair value of each stock option grant.
884219_18_ITEM7_P82_S1	These assumptions include our expected stock price volatility, the expected period of time the stock option will remain outstanding of which stock options have a ten-year life, the expected dividend yield on our common stock, and the risk-free interest rate.
884219_18_ITEM7_P82_S2	While we have not granted stock options since 2010, changes in the assumptions of any future grants could result in different estimates of the fair value of stock option grants, and consequently impact our future results of operations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P82_S3	Refer to Note 2 Share-Based Compensation of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this 2017 Form 10-K) for further information.
884219_18_ITEM7_P82_S4	Impact of Recent Accounting Pronouncements Refer to Note 1 Overview and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Part II, Item 8 of this 2017 Form 10-K) for further information.
884219_18_ITEM7_P83_S0	Non-GAAP Measures In addition to disclosing financial results that are determined in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ), we also disclose non-GAAP financial measures of Adjusted EBITDA, Segment operating income, organic revenue, and organic segment operating income (collectively, the Non-GAAP Measures ).
884219_18_ITEM7_P83_S1	The presentation of the Non-GAAP Measures is supplemental to, but not as a substitute for, other measures of financial performance reported in accordance with GAAP.
884219_18_ITEM7_P83_S2	As not all companies use identical calculations, the Non-GAAP Measures may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.
884219_18_ITEM7_P83_S3	We believe the presentation of the Non-GAAP Measures provides useful information to investors regarding our results of operations for trending, analyzing, and benchmarking the performance and value of our business.
884219_18_ITEM7_P84_S0	Adjusted EBITDA is net income attributable to Viad before our portion of interest expense, income taxes, depreciation and amortization, impairment charges and recoveries, changes in accounting principles, and the effects of discontinued operations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P84_S1	Adjusted EBITDA is used to measure the profit and performance of our operations and to facilitate period-to-period comparisons.
884219_18_ITEM7_P84_S2	Refer to the table below for a reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA to the most directly comparable GAAP measure.
884219_18_ITEM7_P85_S0	Segment operating income is net income attributable to Viad before income (loss) from discontinued operations, corporate activities, interest expense and interest income, income taxes, restructuring charges, impairment losses and recoveries, and the reduction for income attributable to noncontrolling interest.
884219_18_ITEM7_P85_S1	Segment operating income is used to measure the profit and performance of our operating segments to facilitate period-to-period comparisons.
884219_18_ITEM7_P86_S0	Organic revenue and organic segment operating income are revenue and segment operating income (as defined above), respectively, without the impact of exchange rate variances and acquisitions, if any, until such acquisitions are included in the entirety of both comparable periods.
884219_18_ITEM7_P87_S0	The impact of exchange rate variances is calculated as the difference between current period activity translated at the current period s exchange rates and the comparable prior period s exchange rates.
884219_18_ITEM7_P87_S1	We believe that the presentation of organic results permits investors to better understand our performance without the effects of exchange rate variances or acquisitions and to facilitate period-to-period comparisons and analysis of our operating performance.
884219_18_ITEM7_P87_S2	Refer to the Results of Operations section of this MD A for reconciliations of organic revenue and organic segment operating income to the most directly comparable GAAP measures.
884219_18_ITEM7_P88_S0	The Non-GAAP Measures are considered useful operating metrics as potential variations arising from taxes, depreciation and amortization, debt service costs, impairment charges and recoveries, changes in accounting principles, and the effects of discontinued operations are eliminated, thus resulting in additional measures considered to be indicative of our ongoing operations and segment performance.
884219_18_ITEM7_P88_S1	Although the Non-GAAP Measures are used as financial measures to assess the performance of the business, the use of these measures is limited because these measures do not consider material costs, expenses, and other items necessary to operate our business.
884219_18_ITEM7_P88_S2	These items include debt service costs, non-cash depreciation and amortization expense associated with long-lived assets, expenses related to U.S. federal, state, local and foreign income taxes, impairment charges or recoveries, and the effects of accounting changes and discontinued operations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P88_S3	Since the Non-GAAP Measures do not consider the above items, a user of our financial information should consider net income attributable to Viad as an important measure of financial performance because it provides a more complete measure of our performance.
884219_18_ITEM7_P88_S4	A reconciliation of net income attributable to Viad to Adjusted EBITDA is as follows:
884219_18_ITEM7_P89_S0	The increase in Adjusted EBITDA during 2017 was primarily due to higher segment operating income at Pursuit and a decrease in restructuring charges.
884219_18_ITEM7_P89_S1	The increase in Adjusted EBITDA in 2016 was primarily due to higher segment operating income at GES and Pursuit.
884219_18_ITEM7_P89_S2	Refer to the Results of Operations section of this MD A for a discussion of fluctuations.
884219_18_ITEM7_P90_S0	Forward-Looking Non-GAAP Financial Measure We also provide segment operating income as a forward-looking Non-GAAP Measure within the Results of Operations section of this MD A.
884219_18_ITEM7_P90_S1	We do not provide a reconciliation of this forward-looking Non-GAAP Measure to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure because, due to variability and difficulty in making accurate forecasts and projections and/or certain information not being ascertainable or accessible, not all of the information necessary for a quantitative reconciliation of this forward-looking Non-GAAP Measure to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure is available without unreasonable efforts.
884219_18_ITEM7_P90_S2	Consequently, any attempt to disclose such reconciliation would imply a degree of precision that investors could find confusing or misleading.
884219_18_ITEM7_P90_S3	It is probable that this forward-looking Non-GAAP Measure may be materially different from the corresponding GAAP Measure.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Our foreign operations are primarily in Canada, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Germany, and to a lesser extent, in certain other countries.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The functional currency of our foreign subsidiaries is their local currency.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Accordingly, for purposes of consolidation, we translate the assets and liabilities of our foreign subsidiaries into U.S. dollars at the foreign exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P0_S3	The unrealized gains or losses resulting from the translation of these foreign denominated assets and liabilities are included as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P0_S4	As a result, significant fluctuations in foreign exchange rates relative to the U.S. dollar may result in material changes to our net equity position reported in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We do not currently hedge our equity risk arising from the translation of foreign denominated assets and liabilities.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P1_S1	We recorded cumulative unrealized foreign currency translation losses in stockholders equity of $12.0 million as of December 31, 2017 and $29.1 million as of December 31, 2016.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P1_S2	We recorded unrealized foreign currency translation gains in other comprehensive income of $17.1 million during of the year ended December 31, 2017 and foreign currency translation losses of $5.8 million during the year ended December 31, 2016.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P1_S3	For purposes of consolidation, revenue, expenses, gains, and losses related to our foreign operations are translated into U.S. dollars at the average foreign exchange rates for the period.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P1_S4	As a result, our consolidated results of operations are exposed to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates as revenue and segment operating results of our foreign operations, when translated, may vary from period to period, even when the functional currency amounts have not changed.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P1_S5	Such fluctuations may adversely impact overall expected profitability and historical period-to-period comparisons.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	We do not currently hedge our net earnings exposure arising from the translation of our foreign revenue and segment operating results.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Refer to Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (Part II, Item 7 of this 2017 Form 10-K) for a discussion on the Foreign Exchange Rate Variances .
884219_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	A hypothetical change of 10% in the Canadian dollar exchange rate would result in a change to 2017 operating income of approximately $4.6 million.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P3_S1	A hypothetical change of 10% in the British pound exchange rate would result in a change to 2017 operating income of approximately $0.4 million.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P3_S2	A hypothetical change of 10% in the Euro exchange rate would result in a change to 2017 operating income of approximately $0.5 million.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	We are exposed to foreign exchange transaction risk, as our foreign subsidiaries have certain revenue transactions denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the respective subsidiary.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P4_S1	From time to time, we utilize forward contracts to mitigate the impact on earnings related to these transactions due to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P4_S2	As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, we did not have any foreign currency forward contracts outstanding.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P4_S3	We are exposed to short-term and long-term interest rate risk on certain of our debt obligations.
884219_18_ITEM7A_P4_S4	We do not currently use derivative financial instruments to hedge cash flows for such obligations.
